video_title: Full Flight of Insta360 Weather Balloon Flight (Plus Fighter Jet Fly By!)
comment_text: If you focus on the ground instead of the horizon, you will see an obvious distortion in several places on the lens, particularly at 2x speed. The fluctuation in the horizon is slight, but also apparent. The horizon does appear to have a curve later in the video, but the math is wrong on the curve based on the distance and current globe calculations, so we can assume that any fluctuating horizon is due to how the lens focuses the picture. The horizon is more steadily horizontal on the flight up, though again with slight fluctuating along the line. Another detail is that the horizon always stays at eye/lens level and never falls/curves away, indicating an ongoing plane (flat area) of Earth and not a rounded shape of Earth. Interesting to note is that there are no stars and there is no moon at this height.  To burn any assumptions, I'm neither a flat earther nor a round earther (nor any other shape earther). These items were interesting, so I thought to mention to them.

video_title: What is the Best Laser Cutter and Engraver for You?
comment_text:
I actually have a CO2 laser that cuts metal. I imported a full size 4x8 table from China. It has two heads. I only paid $8500

The key to being able to cut metal is POWER. You need your laser tube to be rated at 180w (peak) with 150w nominal. So don't only get a 150w tube and think you've got enough power. (Maybe for super thin sheet metal) The way you can find out if the laser you are looking at can even begin to cut metal, is the head. They are significantly more chunky, look industrial. But they are known in the biz as "Metal/Non-Metal" heads. That's the phrase you are looking for. My table came with a water chiller, up/down front half table, 2 blower motor fume extractors, extra honeycomb top, rotary attachment and small aquarium pump. But I'm using a silent air compressor, it barely needs any real PSI above 40 anyway. And believe it or not, all of it runs on a 120v. (Even though I just converted the actual table to 220v, so I'm not tripping breakers running the water chiller, blower fans and an air compressor all at once. I had to do the extension cord thing across the shop for awhile to catch different outlets not on the same circuit)

More about the head I use to cut steel with... It can cut up to 4mm mild steel and 3mm stainless. Which is crazy to think about, considering the price point. The other thing you will absolutely need is a bottle of oxygen from a welding supply store. You only need to use that when cutting steel. So it's a minor cost factor even if you are just messing around. The other benefit of that particular head is that it can also cut 1" thick acrylic, with glassy smooth polished edges. The secondary head I mentioned, I only use really for cutting thin stuff, most mostly engraving. I believe that one is rated at 80w peak.

video_title: What is the Best Laser Cutter and Engraver for You?
comment_text: Okay, I find your video both informative and misleading. you mention the TOP laser engravers, However, you do not mention that they are all "Hobby Lasers" and not professional engravers. Nor are any of them ever mentioned in the major trade publications like Engravers Journal.  There you will see article and advertisements for the true top laser engravers. that said I have a big problem with Full Spectrum Laser.  Having done business with both Trotec and Epilog  and having been involved with a number of different types of laser, I find FSL to be the worst company in the business that I know of.  I had a Muse engraver back in 2016. Having had better machines and knowing that the Muse was only a Hobby Laser, I still found it to be a big problem. Files would not load, the Claim that corel draw files were fully compatible a joke. Having a BS in Computer Information Systems (programming major) It was clear the first day that the software had serious flaws. The design part of the software would not even display properly. Some of the tools were partly hidden and there was no way to make them display or usable. The few things that I was able to draw would not save and be available in the main window. The machine itself was flimsy and the cheaply built. Mirrors were not aligned and not easy to align. The claim FSL advertised back in 2016 that the Muse does not need to be connected with the internet to work was a marketing ploy to try to get sales that might have gone to Glowforge. Bottom line here is the claim that the Muse did nt need to be connected to the internet is both true and misleading.  The true part is that the muse can be operated while not connected to the internet. What thye don;t say much about is the fact that you do have to have an internet connection and have the Muse connected to the internet and turned on. FSL sends updates to the Muse all the time. If your machine is not connected it does not receive the updates. History since 2016 has shown that many muse owners that had machines that worked one day found that their Muse would not work at all the next day (After FSL had sent an update).  FSL lies about capabilities of their machines. They advertised that a materials database would be into the Muse. It said that on their web site and I verified it with my salesman before buying. No Muse has ever had the materials database. After I made a fuss on several Facebook forums Full spectrum Laser removed any mention that the Muse was to come with the database.  My first Muse bluescreened the second morning I had it. I let FSL talk me into a replacement machine. Thy lied about that too. First they said that if I would let them send me a replacement machine they would ship it out that same day. And they claimed it would be fully tested and working as advertised. However, that is not what happened at all. FSL waited until my first machine got back to them. Second, the second machine had the exact same problems as the first one. There 30 day 100% refund policy is something they run from. If you call tech support they will try to help you. that is as long as you go along whit what they offer. As soon as you tell them that you want to return your machine for a refund, they stop responding to you completely. Lucky for me I was persistent. I called multiple times a day and send emails several times a day. No response for 8 days. When I did get someone to talk to me he informed me that they would not pay the return shipping. Had I bought a machine and then just decided that I did not want it, that would have been reasonable. However, when you get a machine that clearly has major problems and will not work as advertised they should pay for the return shipping. So I sent the Muse back at a cost to me of $271.73. Then when FSL received the Muse they took more than 30 days before refunding part of my money. Yes, that is correct. They have a restocking fee they take out of your purchase price. Again if i was returning a work machine simply because I did not want it, a restocking fee would be reasonable.  Before I shipped the Muse back I told the at Full Spectrum Laser that I did not think it was right to make the owner of a non working machine be responsible for return shipping and then to add insult to injury charge a restocking fee.  My comments to them were that if they gave me all my money back, I would go away. However, if they did not refund all my money I would make it a point to tell as many people as possible how they do business.  Long story short I lost well over $500 to FLS. The return shipping was $271.73. Then the restocking fee took another $250 of my refund.    The only concession here is I have for my trouble is I did make a fuss on a number of forums. After more than 2 years, I contacted the head guy. we had a phone conversation. At the end of that call FSL did refund my $250 Restocking fee. However, they refused to refund the $271.73 I paid to ship their Muse back to them.  Not to long after returning the Muse I started a fb group called Muse Buyers. There I now have well over 400 members. Some have Muse engravers. Several tried to return their machine for refund. FSL stalled and would not respond to them. once the 30 day refund period ends they will respond but will not take back your machine. To be fair, of the members of my group that own a Muse, a few  have only goo things to say about it. However there are more members that have a Muse that does not work.

video_title: Is a 40W CO2 Laser Cutter Worth?  OM Tech K40 Review
comment_text:
Wonder if you could somehow get a thunder laser machine sponsored. Seems like there's a bunch of improvements over the typical chinese laser, things that you won't see on a spec sheet and might not even appreciate until actually using it (or in my case, using an inferior laser with much to be desired).

I have a now discontinued bodor machine and it's just to subpar. There's a few videos on it but surprisingly, there aren't a lot of in depth reviews on laser cutters of any brand. For example, i can't find any videos going super in depth on trotec machines aside from the content that trotec puts out. Which to be fair, is very good quality.

Anyway some aspects that you don't hear much about:

- bed/table system (positioning, locking or other features)
- quality of honeycombs (size, shape, material, framing)
- depth under table and debris collection system if any
- airflow design
- air assist system and features

I think the reason is there's a very small crossover between buyers of the more expensive CO2 lasers and content creators. Everyone's busy making stuff.

video_title: Testing the OM Tech K40 Laser
comment_text:
I'm interested to see how you come along with this machine.  I really like mine but I'm inexperienced with laser engraving.  I've had 3d printers for years, so I like small CNC machines like this...   So far, I've mostly been playing around and working ON the machine doing upgrades, not so much WITH the machine, but that's not a complaint and not due to any fault of the machine. It worked 'fine' out of the box. 

I wanted to mention the grounding to you though.  They paint the shell before they put the grounding hardware in.  You will likely find that you don't have a good earth ground to shell and it could be very dangerous.  Following advice of others, I removed the washer and ground it bare under the washer.  I also did the same under the PS, but prob was overkill.  I plan to replace the power inlet and 120 plugs on the back because they are garbage.  I also don't like the fact that full line voltage goes all the way to the power switch on the control panel then back down to the PS.  I want to replace the inlet with a better quality unit with dual pole switch built in so there is no voltage inside the control chamber at all when i have my hands in there. I wanted to make sure you and anyone else with one of these knew about the poor grounding since it's a pretty serious safety issue.   Before I fixed it, i did get a pretty decent shock by touching the edge of the sheet metal where the paint was thin.  Some people recommend to run a direct connection to earth ground with its own ground spike. (Do your own research though, I'm not an electrician just trying not to shock myself or burn the house down LOL)

You do need to get an ammeter in there asap so you can tell what's actually going on with laser power.  You simply connect it between Cathode of the laser tube and the PS.  If the needle moves backward, reverse it

Over all I'm happy with the OM Tech though.  I ordered a different "K40" at first.  When it arrived it had been dropped and dented badly so I returned it.  Long story short, the seller was a jerk so I eventually got it refunded by UPS and ordered this machine instead.  I'm glad I did.  This one is much sturdier and just generally better.  I've mostly been learning about the control system so far and upgrading the electronics.  I figure I should understand how it works and get everything working as well as possible before I actually start learning more about laser engraving.  I like to know my machines so I know how to repair them when they break. Like with drones, if you don't build it yourself, what are ya gonna do when ya crash it?? LOL  It's much harder to learn on a machine that isn't up to par.  We all know going in that these machines are good, but need upgrades to be great.  So far, I have mine running Marlin on a SKR1.4t.  With TMC2209s, its super quiet and both drivers and motors stay cool.  Having lots of inputs and outputs gives me lots of options for firmwares or things like Gcode/Macro Button control of case lighting and the red dot.  I'm working on adding a relay board today so I can do the same with air and water pump etc.  I added the smallest gas strut I could find to the door bc I accidentally slammed it shut a couple times lol.  I also ran an LED strip with a micro switch on the control side so it comes on like a fridge when I open the door LMAO.   It has been a bit of a bumpy road with Marlin though, so once I'm happier with my config ans engraving speeds, I'll share it so it's easier for others to use inexpensive boards like this instead of the pricey ones.  I believe Smoothie may even be more appropriate for lightburn and will run on SKR/MKS... Will find out later haha.  I haven't added air assist yet because I'm hesitant to order the wrong pump in effort to save $ and still debating, but it's time so I have to choose a compressor asap.  

I really enjoy your work brother.  Keep it up

video_title: What is a 3D Laser Cutter?  Full Spectrum Muse 3D Review
comment_text:
I have had my Muse 3D for about eight months now.  As a machine and a piece of hardware I agree with your review:  this is an outstanding machine that looks great, is well designed and solidly built and cuts and engraves extremely well.  As with any complex device, you will encounter difficulties with various things (such as alignment and belt adjustment),  but their customer service has been outstanding and such issues are totally normal with any laser.

My issue with the Muse is  the software that runs it: re3.  In my hands, this is a horrible piece of software that is slow,  non-intuitive, confusing, constantly freezes my laptop, and is so frustrating to use that I may in fact sell my Muse because of the constant battles I have had with the software. I consider myself proficient with software and have used numerous programs, but at every turn, I have found difficulties with re3.   Interestingly,  re3 looks very similar to Lightburn,  but Lightburn is extremely well designed, intuitive, and  is an absolute joy to use.  It just has a polished "feel" and ease of use that re3 totally lacks.  In my opinion, re3 is a high school software project while Lightburn is sleek, professional and easy.  If only re3 were as well "built" as the Muse itself this would be an awesome combination. 

One thing I have learned , and one should consider when buying a laser, is that when you purchase a proprietary device such as the Muse or the Glowforge for example, (I don't know anything about the Dremel)  you are totally dependent on the software and interface supplied by the respective companies.  For example, if Glowforge should fold as a company, your laser would be completely useless as it runs only via the company internet.  Although the Muse would not suffer a similar fate as the re3 software is on the machine, if you like re3, great, but if you don't, you are stuck.  So basically, by going with a proprietary machine you are exchanging the convenience of a "plug and play" device (obviously a great advantage) but totally giving up any flexibility or controlof the machine  to the respective company.

I sincerely hope FS Laser comes out with a useful re3 update soon.

video_title: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?
comment_text: It seems like perhaps you don't know very much about skechup. Almost everything, not everything, but almost everythig you did in fusion you can do in sketchup. Are you aware of any of the following plugins; curviloft, sub d tools, flowify, soap,  bezier spline, curic stretch, fredo box stretch etc. There are so many plugins in sketchup that are extremely powerful for quick organic manipulation. I think there are some great points about fusion here but it's a poor comparison video because you don't talk about sketchup pro, why just talk about sketchup, sketchup pro is really where the power is, not sketchup because it's about the available plugins that are within sketchup that are incredible. You certainly don't have to go and do things from scratch like you mention in your video. I would say that after watching this and the lack of these comments that I've just mentioned that this video is a poor comparison video and you should perhaps be informed well on both products before you generalize the two together in a comparison because it's very confusing for people like in your comments section who are unsure about which they need for their modelling projects.

video_title: Fusion 360 - Did Autodesk just kill the FREE Version?
comment_text: Thanks for all of this.  Any word on if they're going to fix the 1:1 printing bug before they take away the create-pdf workaround?  The bug was still in existence as of January (the last time I forgot and sent something directly to my printer to print full size).  You send something to a printer (full size, everything set correctly to print 1:1), and Fusion prints at something like 93% scale for no reason.  I printed several patterns, used them to cut out the parts I was making, and about 6 hours later I realized everything was undersized.  The workaround was to create a PDF, then print THAT at 1:1 and it works fine.

video_title: Can I Stain a Maple Butcher Block Countertop?
comment_text: It‚Äôs all about the time you spend sanding the hardwood...and sanding it correctly, and you my friend did NOT sand that wood correctly. You have to start the sanding process at about a 60 grit and work your way all the way to at least 320 or even finer. 60, 80, 120, 180, 220, 320...in that order. It‚Äôs a pain in the ass but if you want a hard wood like maple to look the way it‚Äôs should then that‚Äôs the way you gotta do it...otherwise leave it raw or lime wax it.

comment_text:
nice review....when $ is no object....My advice for anyone is read reviews and watch a lot...a lot of videos. Then so you dont throw your $ in the ocean....buy a K40 laser. Ya i know, its chinese, its unsafe, etc, etc..... you dont have to be a rocket scientist with these....i bought one on amazon, did a tweek here and there. I use inkscape (free)....and scorchworks (free) to use this K40 laser, and it works great....dont have to deal with chinese software.... you learn alot, the cost is super minumum.... if you dont like it, or you get bored with it, sell it on craigslist for  $200....lesson learned.
sooooo. to wrap things up.....Couple years ago, i built my own. bigger and better c02 laser and still using free software. Cost me $1500 to make, and i have more than made up the cost to make it.....life treating me fine right now....retired. Learned off the K40, reading reviews, watching you-tube videos......then make your own.....cant tell you how many people have made their own.....a ton.

video_title: What is the Best Laser Cutter and Engraver for You?
comment_text:
Nice video. Wish you focused more on the higher end lasers but not really your target audience and not something you have in the shop. I wouldn't put boss anywhere near epilog. 
For general use CO2 lasers I would do a list like this:
- K40 + upgrades
- 50W ebay/ali chinese
- 80W ebay/ai chinese
- All in ones or what you call kickstarter lasers (including the more expensive dremel brand one)
- Branded chinese lasers with local support (boss, thunder, aeon etc)
- Finally top tier RF lasers (epilog, trotec, ULS etc)
There's plenty of specific machines that fall outside those categories. Like aeon having an 'all in one' style series and thunder laser having RF source lasers.

video_title: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?
comment_text:
Sketchup has never adapted to 3D printing and struggles with small objects. This has some work arounds but the program is basically for architectural design. Maintaining solid mesh and other objects is often difficult with Sketchup.
Fusion 360 isn't perfect either but it has so many builtin functions that most things seem to be possible. 
Blender has so many modes it's frustrating for 3D printing and engineering design. It's so hard to get into I gave up.

video_title: Is this the BEST budget Laser Engraver? Ortur Laser Master Engrave 2 Review
comment_text: Yeaaa‚Ä¶ I wouldn't trust those even being in the 2W range... The X-Carve CNC Milling Machine in my basement ( https://imgur.com/a/04LhFJN ) has had an *Opt Lasers PLH3D-6W-XF* Laser Head attached to it which trust a LOT more being what it is marketed as than anything else coming from the Asian regions of the world ( Unless it had _Made in Japan_ stamped on it ). I also think what most people miss out on is that those Lasers don't just pose a threat to your sight when looking into the Laser with line of sight but they also pose an issue with reflections ( light bouncing off a mirror ) and refractions ( shining a strong flashlight _through_ your hand ). Besides THAT there's also the issue with cutting certain materials - Laser cutting ABS, as an example, will emit Cyanide!

video_title: Can I Stain a Maple Butcher Block Countertop?
comment_text: These pre-made butcher blocks are already pretty smooth. Hand sand with the grain and only use a fine or ultra fine sand paper or sanding block. Treat it with pre-stain and then stain. Make sure the prestain and the stain are either both water-based or both oil-based. If you decide to sand in between finishes, make sure to also use something that's ultra fine like 400 grit. Also do it within 24 hours of taking the wrapping off.

video_title: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?
comment_text:
I'm pretty deep into Sketchup and just a baby at Fusion 360.

Sketchup crashes a lot (for me). And it can't import-export unless you want to cough up a good chunk of changed.  I can get quite a bit done. Sketch-u-cam helps a lot. It's a bit limited and buggy too.

It's a bit early in the game but F360 looks quite promising. I'm already doing things in it that would be completely hairy in sketchup.

I'm going to argue that Sketchup is great at the beginning since you can get going pretty fast with it and there's a reasonable gamut of stuff you can do with it using a 2.5D methodology. Great for the dating stage with your cnc machine. 


But if you are going to marry your cnc machine a person should add F360 to the mix. You'll be able to delve deeper.

video_title: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?
comment_text:
Some nice information! However, I'm still not convinced... Lots of the stuff you showed like resizing the countertop and drawer can be done very quickly in Sketchup as well. I see all these tables and screens full of dimensions and numbers, but I think with some experience you will be faster in Sketchup in the end, since it's so easy to use.


For the organic sculpting there are very good and simple to use plugins for Sketchup. And as for printing, Sketchup can export directly to STL as well, I use it for 80% of my printer modeling (and some blender sometimes). The built-in slicer in Fusion is cool, but if you're used to a normal slicer like Cura or Slic3r already, this doesn't have much more value over using Sketchup.


About rendering...  I actually use Sketchup for this professionally,  with a plugin called Twilight Render. It may not be as powerful as for example Vray ( which also costs an insane amount of money), but it can make REALLY realistic renders, better than anything i've seen coming out of Fusion.


Now... I'm not saying that Fusion is bad; If you want to do some complex and organic modeling and product design, though it can be done, it's not very easy in Sketchup. For extremely parametric stuff, like the lego bricks you showed us, this will be better as well. But I still think people really write off Sketchup too quickly, and often overlook what that piece of software can do with some additional plugins, ESPECIALLY for interior design and non-organic stuff like that. The workflow and interface sure are infinitely more intuitive and simple than any other modeling software out there...


You're free to use what you want of course, both are valid options, but don't underestimate Sketchup if you like a really hands-on and intuitive workflow.

comment_text:
I don't know what some of these people are going on about with the antifreeze BS, but don't do that. Run pure distilled water only and put a couple drops of dish detergent and a cap full of bleach in it.  If you don't want to use bleach, then at least add fish tank bio killer in the water to prevent it from going stagnant over time.  Using antifreeze or "water wetter" products and the like is bad, because it cooks into the glass and actually will eventually build heat on the tube, as will minerals in the water if it's not pure distilled.  Don't listen to these dopes.  I've been running home built units for years now and have done the research for 10 men.
Also invest in a CW-5000 chiller and be done with it.  Doing anything less is asking for future issues in all reality.

video_title: Does a $200 Laser Engraver Make Sense in Your Shop?
comment_text:
Also, worth noting, those included glasses aren't rated for the laser on the machine. The tint vs color of the laser is a dead giveaway. If you look at any laser engraver and many high powered laser pointers of similar wavelength, the protective shielding or goggles are orange. It's basically a principle of opposing colors. It helps if you think of the color of the goggles cancelling out the color of the laser. In this case, the blue laser light is extremely close to the green goggles on the color wheel. The goggles let light in and around the green wavelength through. For the goggles to be effective in blocking the blue laser light, they should be red, or preferably orange, the opposing color to blue. 

Since they aren't clear or blue goggles, they are probably blocking some of the harmful light, but I definitely wouldn't trust my vision to them, especially if they were included free with a cheap and cheerful, safety measure delete laser engraver.

Edit: It might be worse than I thought...I was just basing this off of a combination of my knowledge of optics, confirmed by the high end laser related products I've seen. I just looked it up and found this video. It looks like he has a pair of the included glasses, and they fail to even block an LED, so if you're staring at the laser light, you're probably roasting your retinas.
https://youtu.be/upCsVrKrW7M

He also has an epic accent.

Edit 2: Here's a video that goes more into depth on what you should look for in goggles to protect yourself. I am pretty confident that the ones included above are just green plastic, with no laser rating whatsoever. If one is listed, I'd be willing to bet that it's utter BS.

Long and short of it, if you're gonna save a buck on your laser engraver, don't skimp on the PPE to go along with it. Or you'll be giving yourself anti-lasik.

Final Edit: I'm also only considering the harmful potential of the unshielded laser module. This is ignoring the carcinogen laden fumes it's outputting. There is a reason laser cutters are enclosed both behind laser shielded material AND have their own filtration and extraction systems. This could also very easily start a fire if you're not watching it like a hawk, and even if you are, I can see a mosquito fart knocking it over, or it overshooting the material it's engraving and scorching the surface beneath it. 

As much as I want a laser cutter, this seems like a bad idea. 3d printers and CNC routers are one thing to downsize and lose all the safety gear. The damage they can do is pretty limited to localized burns and possibly losing a digit to a router bit. Laser cutters are next level dangerous.

video_title: 6 Mistakes Not to Make When Building a Farmhouse Table
comment_text:
Breadboard style edge is probably a more accurate description. Its the old way to stabilize the warping of, you guessed it, a breadboard.
Tip - when you peg the breadboard, elongate the peg holes in the main body of the table aside from the center peg.
This allows the table top to expand and contract without splitting the boards or your glue joints.

video_title: 6 Mistakes Not to Make When Building a Farmhouse Table

comment_text:
Depends on what you want to do.

To mess around and learn a bit while possibly making useful trinkets... these little machines are a good start.

Low cost and see if you are actually going to do anything at all with it.

When you find that the stuff you want to CNC carve is not going to be able to be done on the little machine, change it to a laser engraver and get a better CNC machine.

These little things will make some nice looking coasters and key chains and carve the color layered plastics for small signs.

Not good for engraving brass really.

If you want to make a small number of thin aluminum sheet metal parts for RC models, the 3018 series CNC can do the trick.

video_title: 6 Mistakes Not to Make When Building a Farmhouse Table
comment_text:
I'm about to say something that will make the wood movement police go crazy. But whatever. Lol. My experience supports it. 

Wood movement... It's a "common tale" that as external humidity changes, so will your projects... Well... That's honestly not the case if you have your home well insulated and at a consistent humidity. Which most houses are. Most antique furniture doesn't break from wood movement when sitting in a house.... They break from wood movement when people put them in garages and barns where there is no climate control. Then the wood movement starts setting in and everything gets all crazy. And also .. wood movement can be overpowered and controlled. Just look at high quality sheets of veneer ply. 

If you are building something for an interior job, honestly it will likely shrink a little over the next 1-6 months when bringing it in from your shop (especially if your shop isn't well controlled with it's humidity and temperature .)

I've sold very expensive veneered signs, laminated chess boards with highly figured cross grain, and even tables with cross grain on them. As long as you expect a little shrinkage and it's gonna be climate controlled.... You honestly don't need much for wood movement. 

You don't believe me? Go to the Las Vegas airport and go to the Jamba Juice inside the terminal. There is a hickory table there with no proper breadboards, held all together with glue and dominos. Breaks all the rules and it's perfectly flat and strong with perfect joints. 

Also, the Samurai Carpenter and many of my fellow pro woodworker friends agree with me. Yes wood moves. But not as much as people think on indoor furniture. And a little known fact about wood glue.... It's actually not a true solid once cured. It can allow for a surprising amount of wood movement and shifting and still keep it's bond. Honestly man you could have just glued and mortise and tenoned that baby on for the breadboard. The bigger issue isn't the breadboard... It's the fact that you are using construction lumber. The 2x6s are gonna get way more contraction than just going down to the hardwood store and buying poplar. And it actually will be surprisingly similar in cost. But the moisture in that framing lumber may be enough that it blows that a perpendicular wood joint out. But if you are using dry high quality woods... My statement stands.

video_title: The Most Powerful Laser Diode? NEJE Master 2S Plus A40640 Laser
comment_text:
Informative video. One thing I want to add is that you should always be wearing laser goggles when The machine is on. This is true even if the laser is in low power mode. Even in low power mode I'm sure it could blind you instantly if you got a reflection just right. Given the price level of these things are built to it's also entirely possible for the laser to just go into high power mode on its own to do some sort of circuitry or programmatical failure.
A good quality set of laser goggles is probably the most important thing you can buy when dealing with anything laser. Also make sure it is the right goggles for the wavelength of laser you are using.

video_title: The Most Powerful Laser Diode? NEJE Master 2S Plus A40640 Laser
comment_text:
The Comgrow Z1 is even worse. 4 thumbscrews and 2 U channels. I'm working on a better method.

I took the red shield off of my Z1. It was getting crudded up w/ debris. For cutting thicker materials it also gets in the way because there's only a 2mm gap at optimal surface focus.

I made a temporary enclosure out of cardboard and piped in a 170cfm (advertised flow) exhaust blower. It's not ideal or the safest enclosure material, but I never leave the laser unattended when in operation and have a small ABC extinguisher nearby. The blower is marginal for extracting the smoke, but that's likely due to the "enclosure" having an open front.


Mine is good to etch at faster than 9000, but at those speeds I haven't tested the accuracy. For slate coasters, it will even produce a textured surface at medium speeds.

video_title: 6 Mistakes Not to Make When Building a Farmhouse Table
comment_text:
Sure i'm not the first to comment on this, but all of you outer tongue pin holes should be elongated along the width axis of the table, otherwise they will fight the expansion of the wood and you could end up with some weird movement.

Also, offset the breadboard holes 1/16" out compared to the tongue holes so the pins actually draw the joint closed when they go in (called draw boring).

Obviously this is more of a "tips" video than a full on how to, so you probably already knew/did these things. Just thought i'd share in case you didnt :)

video_title: Is this the BEST budget Laser Engraver? Ortur Laser Master Engrave 2 Review
comment_text:
I received this laser this week and I have to say it is a sexy POS.  They say it works now with lightburn, well it does not.    I have had nothing but problems with it.  It crashes into the wall all the time.  When you tell it to home, it crashes into the wall.  If you try to frame your work to tell where you need to put you material, it crashes into the wall.  There are no limit switches on this laser so it has no idea where it is.  If you want to put your work in the middle of the field, well good luck.  I tried everything and it would only work in the upper left corner.  There is no emergency stop switch, so if you have a problem you have to fumble  around for the power switch.  Not something you want to do if you have a real problem.  I ordered the rotary with this laser but did not get it.  I had to contact support to find out that it was on backorder, and they never even thought to email me to let me know.  There is no factory air assist with this laser, and that would defiantly come in handy.  Their setup video is horrible.  It moves so fast that you can't really tell what they are doing and what part that are using.  I have to say DON'T buy this if you are new to laser engraving, and even if you are a seasoned  person it will be hard to get it to work properly.  Do yourself a favor and stay away from this laser.  Sorry to put this up but I think it will help a lot of people.  This is not a well thought out machine. Yeah it looks sexy and well built but it's not worth the price at all.  I will be getting an Ortur for sure.
I do think that you can learn a lot from this channel though.  He really seems to know his stuff.  Keep the videos coming, and thank you for all you do for this hobby.

The software is very poor and limits your abilities to use this to its fullest capacity.  I bought it for the 10w laser, but had I known it would not use industry standard software, I would have made a different choice.
By the way, do not upgrade from laserbox basic 1.1.0 to 1.0.1 it breaks the positioning ability on the burn screen.  The earlier version works when you try to position the laser using the buttons to go left, right, up or down.  On the new release, it seems to be very harsh on the motors and the laser starts moving diagonally (not in a straight line) as intended.  Again, the software is beta release at best.

video_title: Should you upgrade a budget laser cutter?
comment_text:
Great video. First point. Most K40s come with kill switch on the lid now. Second, Meerk4t will allow a lot more flexibility to your laser power, I think it does fast switching rather than varying the power.. It's not in Lightburn territory but it's way better than Whisperer and it's free.
Third, the fan is upgraded, most now come with a perfectly adequate fan, rather than that dire fan on earlier models. Remove the internal ducting and you have really good extraction.
This means that you will only be spending around $100 for air assist and mirrors to get a very workable machine that competes with the Glowforge on most jobs.

video_title: The Best Laser Cutter for any Budget?
comment_text: Good info, thanks. I built my own laser cutter/engraver using a 15W (optical power) diode laser. The gantry is made using 3D printed parts and 2040 aluminum extrusions. Will need to install an air assist system to improve deep cuts. The only thing missed in this video is discussing how some sellers of diode lasers mislead buyers by specifying the power used by the diode rather than it's actual optical (cutting/engraving) power. As an example, I have another diode laser that is sold as a "15W" laser but actually puts out around 4.5 watts of cutting/engraving power. 15 watts is the amount of power it requires from a power supply.

video_title: SparkMaker LaserPro: The new King üëë of budget laser engravers?
comment_text: The software that is shipped with the LaserPro is buggy and and not very powerful. LaserPro is not compatible with Lightburn - yet - they are working on it. However after several weeks playing with it, I found that with a very simple GCODE header and footer added to the Lightburn configuration file, the LaserPro will (mostly) run with Lightburn. It has a very small spot and is very powerful. It easily cuts 3mm plywood at 225mm/min at 95% power, and engraves literally everything. It has an internal fan that provides air assist, blowing air from the same orifice as the laser, and the lens is recessed in the laser head so smoke does not settle out on the lens. The auto focus works great, and the enclosure with the fan lets you vent the smoke out a window. The video camera takes a bit of careful setup but is extremely useful. When the LaserPro is fully Lightburn compatible it will definitely be the diode laser engraver to buy. My LaserPro is now the one I use for all my projects, and my previous laser engraver (which I was very happy with) sits pretty much idle.

video_title: The Nicest Laser Engraver This Year? The xTool D1 Review
comment_text: I'd love your opinion on our use case of this vs the Ortur. Was just about to go for the Ortur LM2 Pro when I saw this video. Eithers' most difficult and frequent use case would be for a teacher cutting paper, cardboard, and occasional thin (6mm or less basswood/balsawood) for young student projects. Along with doing engraving for gifts and occasional sales (once or twice a year flea markets, no online shop).  Would a 4" hose and exhaust fan to outside *near* the xTool be enough in a basement shop? I've got preexisting 4" exhausts running for airbrush and resin 3d printers. Or should we really use an enclosure?  Really like the xTool build quality and what seems to be a better laser module with dual diode. "Good enough" software doesn't seem to be a problem since it doesn't need a persistent online connection like glowforge. The big thing that has me hesitating on this xTool is that the Ortur has an optional enclosure, seems to have more reviews, more mods, and more units actually out there in the hands of hobbyists.

video_title: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?
comment_text:
Good video, however just about everything you said sketchup cant do.....it can. For one, model using dynamic components. You can not only change sizing on the fly but you can also animate door openings, drawers and check for collisions etc. This is HUGE! You can change material thickness etc. Rendering....well, that depends on what you are trying to accomplish. Sketchup uses companies like VRay and Lumion..... Fusion 360s internal renderer cant compare. That does require an additional software purchase, but being that was a point brought up I assume we are focusing on quality of render potential and Vray simply cant be touched. One huge advantage Sketchup has over Fusion 360 is Layout, the quality and ease of use to create amazing drawings is a big need for me. Again both of these programs are solid, it just depends on what you are doing and what you need. I would not count sketchup out as it is very powerful, and even more so when paired with quality plugins. I do like Fusions CAM capability though, I currently export to Aspire, but 3d shapes would
 be nice to toolpath on screen like that. Thanks for the video!

comment_text:
The ORTUR looks like it be good for some DIY 3D printer, with some modifications.

I worked at a place that used a type of plastic powder, in the consistency of baby powder. Wile sitting in it's shaker, it looked like bubbling liquid. Wile in that state, it is sucked up with a positive charge added to it, and sprayed on a metal part with a negative charge, to make the powder paint stick to it. After, it goes into an oven to melt the plastic onto the metal as a covering. Comes in many colors.

If one was to have a table that a slider arm will lay out a thin layer of that powder onto a table, the ORTUR could be use to trace out the shape of one layer to a 3D part. The table would drop by one layer, as the slider arm adds another layer of powder. The ORTUR traces out that next layer, before the table drops again. Repeat, until all layers are complete.

Use a small vac to suck up the unused powder, and you got a 3D part. Trick is, getting the ORTUR to be part of that automated task. Could be make possible with a Raspberry PI I think.

Would prove to be a neat project. And cost vastly less than other 3D printers that do such already costing over 15,000 for a low end 3D printer of that type.

video_title: Should you upgrade a budget laser cutter?
comment_text: After a lot of research I went the modified K40 route. I upgraded lenses & mirrors, added air assist, amp meter, better temp displays and a better internal and external fan. I also expanded the bed area by cutting down the exhaust shroud. I did run through a major tune-up and alignment to really dial everything in before use. I didn't bother with a chiller, a 5-gallon bucket serves me just fine. I also haven't bothered to upgrade the controller board, the original works just fine for my workflow with K40 Whisperer. I mainly use it for cutting plastic or plywood parts for prototyping rather than engraving, so the stock controller is fine. All in, it easily came in under $800 to have a very versatile machine in my arsenal that I can add and upgrade to later if needed.

comment_text: Speaking from my heart you shouldnt mention that these machines have a range of 20-100kHz. Open the machine and check the fiberlaser module and you will see it yourself. If its a "cheap" Raycus this will eventuelly be a QS-Version (RFL-P20QS blue) with a range of 30-60kHz. This is what the chinese guys sell you as an 20-100kHz. If you use it out of this range the module will fail within months. Btw. even the good cheap china fiberlaser modules on these machines are RFL-P20QE versions with have a range of 20-60kHz. So be prepared.

video_title: Should you upgrade a budget laser cutter?
comment_text: The exhaust fan should be at the exhaust end of the tube... that way you're never pressurizing the tubes... you're always pulling air into it.  The reason for this is so that you never push smoke out of the ducting... you're always drawing air through any leaks in it.  (It's always a negative pressure, instead of a positive pressure, in the tubes.)

video_title: The Best Laser Cutter for any Budget?
comment_text: Years ago I worked, extensively, with an Epilogue Summit 2000/25. That machine was built in the mid 90s. Back then you connected to it, as a printer, so Epilogue provided a print driver. Being older it had no USB, so it has a parallel printer port connector. But I "printed" thru Corel Draw, which would both cut and engrave. The engraving portion, was provided with a simple image file format (.jpg, .png, .bmp, etc), and the cutting with a vector format (.dxf), that I imported into corel, to make the final file, to be engraved & cut out. Is this still an option on modern engravers ? The prices on these new units are hobby affordable, as Epilogue units start around $20K, so not going to happen, unless you're in the business.

comment_text:
When it comes to software, it's also worth pointing out which ones rely on online services. I know you said "web based", but not everyone quite gets what that means. Having been screwed by a company going out of business, turning my 3d printer into a brick, I will never buy tools like these that require an online service (as opposed to web-based software served up from the tool, like most routers). For the price of something like the glowforge, I'd want to ensure I could use it for as long as I decide to.

Proprietary software (that they eventually stop updating) is another no-no, but at least you can work around that by keeping a frozen PC around for the life of the tool. No way to work around a service requirement, though.

video_title: Should You Buy a Glowforge?
comment_text:
I didnt hear much about the speed of the glow forge in your review.  Personally, I think it is painfully slow. when I first started looking for a laser, I saw reviews just like this, and got all fired up and excited.  however, after digging deeper, checking out the specs, comparing this to others on the market, and then factoring in the total lack of actual support ( other than the community forums ), having to return the unit to even replace a tube, and for almost every other things, at. great cost - I soon realised, this was actually not a great machine for the money they are demanding for it.  It looks very nice, but, it just doesn't command the price.  

they do an excellent job of marketing, an immense job, but they they would ( in my opinion ) provide a much better product, with support if they pent less on the advertising and more into the product itself.  Once I made an initial enquiry, I was almost hounded by e-mail after e-mail after e-mail.  however when I replied with questions, their answers were always very vague, or often they would deviate from my question, paying lip service to it only, and trying to big up everything else in an attempt to negate my concerns, and convince me that despite my concern, there were so many other aspects that were simply amazing...anyway... hard pass for me im afraid

I love your reviews in general, but I do have to say, I think this one was probably biased as a result of glow forge sending you the laser and air purifier etc..I know you said it wasn't, but it did sound like it.

video_title: Should you upgrade a budget laser cutter?
comment_text: Personally after starting my laser experience with an Orturn 20w diode laser with lightburn, I'm hooked on lightburn. I personally believe it to be better all around then the software you use with the Glowforge. IF the Glowforge used lightburn, I'd save my money and buy one, but lightburn is the tool that tells me it's totally worth buying and upgrading the most expensive chinese laser you/I can afford.  50 or 60 watt IMHO !  Lightburn is just too awesome to not have available.

video_title: Should you upgrade a budget laser cutter?
comment_text:
I started in March with an Ortur Laser Master 2 Diode machine to dip my toes in and see if I liked laser engraving.
Last month I had a OmTech 60w CO2 machine with 20"x28" build surface delivered (eBay).   Got Lightburn when I had the Ortur and was a simple process to upgrade the license to work with the Ruida controller on the 60w machine.  Makes for an amazingly capable machine with plenty of power for my current goals.

I don't think there's anyway I'd be satisfied with a Glowforge.  Proprietary software, internet connection required, and could become a brick any day if the company ever shut down.

Note: Ortur machine sold on Facebook Marketplace within 24 hours for about what I paid for it (of course I included all my upgrades so it was certainly more valuable than stock).

comment_text: There is no argument that the fit and finish of the Glowforge is first rate.  But there are too many limiting factors, especially the closed ecosystem, where even if the company does not fold, you are beholden to their marketing changes.  Just ask any Cricket user of the last couple of months.  Yes, Cricket backed out of their proposed changes, but for a while, there was the potential to basically owning a brick..  Should Glowforge find itself in financial difficulties, what is to stop them from charging for functionality that already exists and is part of the package, or jacking up the cost of their subscription service, after people have integrated the glowforge into their process (if commercial).  Sadly, this is a hard pass for me.

video_title: Should You Buy a Glowforge?
comment_text:
The reviewed equipment adds up to basically $7000. A quick look at OMTech shows you can get 100w, 24x40 (and passthrough), autofocus, a much deeper maximum depth (tumbler engraving anyone?), an actual chiller, two different styles of rotary machines, Corel graphics suite, and Lightburn for $6360. You'll have $640 left to spend on a camera for Lightburn so you'll have the same functionality as SlowForge. You'll also have a much bigger machine with more than twice the power and the ability to fix small things like laser alignment (good luck re-aligning your shiny new Glowforge if it gets bumped during shipping). The only thing you'll be missing is the air purifier and there are plenty of cost effective options out there.

Glowforge shouldn't be compared to a cheap k40; it should be compared to what else you can get for the cost. For the cost, there are much better options.

Btw, their $3000 basic machine gets equally spanked by a 50w OMTech. They do have great advertising though and the entire laser community has benefitted from it.

video_title: Should You Buy a Glowforge?
comment_text:
Personally for the cost, I would rather a 50w and lightburn, sure you will need a chiller and a bigger extractor, but the inability to be able to use a rotary, or a decent thickness of wood and the low power, the hard to clean, the fact you cant repair anything on it your self... Give me a machine I can work on my self every day of the week. 

also closed ecosysytem for software nope sorry thats where pain comes, give it a few years and when glowforge decide they don't want to support it any more tough! (See Cricut for example of this happening) 

Having a sealed path is a terrible idea in my view, replacing mirrors will be needed in the future and I bet that's a return to glow forge for them to do it and if its not then it will be an expensive option .

A few questions, 
1) How long is the laser tube? cos it doesnt look like a real 40W have they done the trick of saying its peak and using that as a selling point, it looks (to me at least) more like a 35w tube. 
2) What's the fluid used for the cooling? does it have a decent amount of fluid in it? considering the size of most chillers they are bigger than the whole machine so what is it using? 
3) What's the max cutting and engraving speed? 
4) How easy to replace the lens? and how expensive? 


My personal opinion is they are over priced and they also could do with someone understanding lasers doing the marketing (its not a printer for example) and to be honest they have a really bad reputation for going wrong due to things like ribbon cables, I guess they are the apple of the laser world, more expensive than a better option and a closed ecosystem .... 

Not for me but others might enjoy it.

comment_text: The fiber laser is unique in that the fibet itself is whar creates the laser light  or more specificly the excited ions doped within the lattice of the crystal or glass fiber. Most of the time or at least for consumer focused fiber lasers they are pumped with a powerful    bank  of LEDs which is the excitation source stimulating the emission of radiation. These types of lasers can be significantly less expensive for maintenance as well as initial cost thanks to the more simple beam path. Obviously there are many other factors involved in the cost of the unit and  quality of the beam,  spectrum of the beam , how the beams pulse shape  and duration are controlled ,  or if it has a continuous wave stable  beam... sorry,  i love lasers haha

comment_text: I have 34 years in the laser Business... I have seen them come and go... the likes of Epilog and Universal.... In 1991 I laser engraved the Weatherby Lazermark for them in Santa Ana CA on a 75-watt LMI ( 145K investment) then Epilog comes along and pitches the summit a 45K Boat Anchor if it was a racehorse it would still be out there trying to finish a mile race! You have to understand what Lasers can do and do not do. I hope I can purchase something again soon now that even a 100-watt cutter and engraver are less than 25K!   Our Laser Shop also did acrylic we had a local shop that had at the time a 600-watt flatbed Mitsubishi and it would cut 1/2 inch acrylic like butter! Miss those days!

comment_text: This is hilarious... I love all the b*%ching & moaning from the "something for nothing" crowd... Fusion is amazing software and even in it's throttled back form, it is a priviledge for the freeloaders to be a ble to use it. I have paid over $40,000 (Australian)  for Solidworks over the years and that is cheap compared to ProEngineer (Creo) and UniGraphics that preceeded it, but Fusion is way superior, especially if you need to use CNC etc, the Delcam / FeatureCam / HSMWorks tech rolled into Fusion is outrageously good for the price. So take your free subscription and go to FreeCAD, or other halfway house for amatuers, and there will be far less wingeing..

comment_text:
Nice Video and has a lot of information in it.    I want to get into a Laser Engraver but of course there is so much info to digest and make decisions on.    Because of the COVID virus we have now lost the only place I would have gone to look at and ask questions about it.  That is FRY's Electronics.  I was going to build a newer computer with newer components.  I like to buy locally and now there is no second choice place to go.  The whole printing and engraving environment is changing so fast I have been deliberately slow to get involved and jump in.  Would you be able to make suggestions on where to focus if I mentioned some of the criteria involved?  1)  Engrave small objects like in the size of Keys, Knife handles and up to the size of 6 inches square for just a little more versatility;  2)  Because of size - price should be small due to the versatility and usefulness is reduced (comparatively);  3)  Precision - due to the size of the engravings they will be examined closely.  4)  Engrave or etch but NOT cut through.  5) Small because of my needs and can't have it take up a lot of room.   6)  Engrave any metals that will dis-color noticeably. 

All these are valid reasons that must be evaluated together.     If you can please give me a few suggestions.  Because I don't know what the prices may be, please consider price to be of the lesser requirement.  I want a good one that will do the job.  Thanks for your help.

video_title: What is the Best Laser Cutter and Engraver for You?
comment_text: I love my beamo.  30w laser. Nice setup, software and camera are great. Can easily hook to my computer.  I think it goes for $1500 (I bought the kickstarter so its obviously a diff price) and I recommend it when ease of use and safety is accounted for. Research your seller to make sure good customer service is available. I haven't had problems and I've used it for about 8 months regularly. I also never cut at 50% to help save my CO2 laser, but thats a personal pref. Never look directly at lasers, always get glasses but you still shouldn't look directly at it with glasses on either.  Also research what materials you are cutting because gases released can be harmful if youre ignorant of what you're cutting. Hope this helps and glhf :)

Engraving stuff is the easy bit. Running s successful business is HARD. My engraving business (operational for 13 years) took three years of 18-hours a day, 7 days a week to develop and become profitable - now serving corporate customers in 22 countries around the world. To infer that simply learning to laser engrave translates into a profitable business is disingenuous. It took me a couple of days to learn to engrave - and nearly 4 years before I saw a meaningful profit.
Viewers need to know that making a kitschy trinket does not necessarily translate into a profitable business...

video_title: Should you buy a Fiber or a CO2 Laser?
comment_text:
You should differentiate the laser beam generation (fiber, disk, CO2, diode) and the beam steering (galvo, gantry) since they are different things and are not to be confused. Otherwise people will think a galvo can be only uses with fiber lasers which is wrong.
It's probably more feasible to use this combination, since fiber lasers usually have a better beam quality than diode lasers (up to 1/100, with one beeing the best and going to inf) and 1/10th the wavelength of CO2. Both increase the ability to focus the beam.

comment_text: Why are galvo lasers not used on a gantry?  it seems like galvo = small work area but fast travel, gantry = slow but big work area. why not do a galvo head on a gantry to get a large work area and a wider (not directly downward) beam on a gantry?  If the galvo head is coupled to a wire source (or other pump configuration), the galvo head should be easily movable relative to the diode bank (my understanding is that fiber optic fibers/wires/cables are flexible and durable).  if the gantry could move the galvo head over a large area, that might also mitigate the other con of galvo heads you mentioned (sub optimal angles at limits of galvo head), because the galvo head wouldn‚Äôt need to be pushed to reach as far to yield a work area that seems competitive (it could stay within an optimal angular range relative to the travel of and on the gantry).  I‚Äôm not currently working in the laser industry so I apologize if this a dumb question.

comment_text:
We have a glowforge midrange machine. Had it for a year running full time. It started having problems. Couldn't get any support from glowforge. It's our business so we bought another to use while the other gets fixed & can be used as a back up. My son basically started just replacing parts & the carriage turned out to be the problem. We had the new machine for 2 months. Nothing but problems with it. It wouldn't cut on normal settings. It also would start randomly not cutting or excessively burning on higher settings. Finally glowforge sent a "referbished" replacement for our brand new 5000$ machine. The refer machine showed up with cooling liguid leaked all over. Tried running the machine at glowforge support request & the entire laser arm is off center running crooked & is completely noisy because the track wheels are worn.
I highly recommend no one buy a glowforge. Their customer service sucks & there is zero product support. Their poor business model is a devistating model for your business if you are trying to run 9ne with glowforge.

video_title: $4000 cheaper than Glowforge AND better?  OMTech Polar Review
comment_text:
I got a glowforge basic back when they were $2k.  I love it, and use it semi-regularly as a hobbyist.  I will say that since seeing them introduce the subscription service and push it so hard, I've had the constant sneaking worry that one day they'll try and lock all function of my glowforge behind a paywall, but so far they haven't done that.  I only ever upload designs so I have no need for the subscription.  If they ever do decide to brick it for a subscription (or go under and their webclient ceases to be), I'll look at other companies, but I can't afford to upgrade as long as I've got a working laser already.

Despite my overall very positive experience with glowforge, I don't think I'd recommend them to someone now, when you can get a more powerful laser that can run in house software for less money.  When it was 2k, it was also one of the only really user friendly lasers on the market, and one of the cheapest lasers.  At twice the price, and still locked into glowforge's online software, I just don't see why anyone would pick it over a competitor.

video_title: $4000 cheaper than Glowforge AND better?  OMTech Polar Review
comment_text:
I received my Polar 350 today.  I also own a zf3551, a FSL PS20, and a custom-built 5w UV.  

I bought it thinking I could use it as a semi-portable.  

Here's my thoughts:

1) Not really meant to be portable.  
2) Very fast from uncrating to lasering.
3) In Lightburn, unless I'm missing something, the focus (z-offset) has to be set for every layer.
4) Camera calibration was easy - except a bit inaccurate (so I guess not as easy as it seemed).  It would not even detect the dot pattern unless I opened the lid part way.  It seemed like Lightburn doesn't like the 180 pano camera lens, but this is my first machine with a camera.   I'll fiddle more tomorrow.

video_title: $4000 cheaper than Glowforge AND better?  OMTech Polar Review
comment_text:
Glowforge is a compete pos. Prior to buying my 50w Omtech, I rented a Glowforge from a friend, and it was 100% unusable because you HAVE TO scan the bed with the camera prior to every burn. So, if you think you‚Äôre going to design something and pound a bunch of them out, 1 after the other, you‚Äôre going to be seriously disappointed. It makes no difference that every piece is on exactly the same material and there is no need to scan every time. You HAVE TO. Their software is crap and replacement parts are more trouble than their worth.

I had a Lightburn camera on my Omtech. I took it out and threw it away. I can‚Äôt imagine what could possibly be the use for something so wildly inaccurate, and that‚Äôs after having spent far too much time mastering the calibration procedure. I‚Äôd disagree with the statement that Omtech support is great. It‚Äôs not. I had an issue with a loose X axis belt. I spent several days going back and forth with them and their suggestions for what to do had nothing - literally zero - to do with the problem, which was a loose belt. I figured it out on my own. Aside from that, I‚Äôve been VERY happy with the machine and I‚Äôm coming up on a year of using it for production manufacturing.

video_title: 6 Mistakes Not to Make When Building a Farmhouse Table
comment_text:
1:25 and even if you don't have a table saw you can just plane it by hand. No need to buy all kinds of powertools.
1:55 dowels are optional. They can help against slippage while gluing, maybe even make the joints marginally stronger, but you don't actually need them.
2:20 this is actually nonsense. If you alternate the directions you're going to get a wavy surface. You're averaging out the warping, but not stopping the warping. If you keep them all in one direction and make sure it wants to bow in an upward arch, if you then fasten the middle securely the entire rail the top rests on will stop it from warping altogether (that is, unless there's so much force the fastening doesn't hold, but you shouldn't get such moisture extremes indoors).
40:20 you did the breadboard wrong. In the board itself you can just drill holes, but the part it slides over can only have a normal drill hole in the middle (to keep the breadboard centered). The other holes need to be elongated slots rather than just holes, so the pins going through them have room to move sideways (but not length wise obviously). Just a few millimeters, but what you've done now is basically the same as screwing the board on. This creates stress. Also, there's no need to glue it in the middle. You can, but you should glue less wide than you did. Just a bit around the centre pin.
 4:20 yup, you need to practice planing. Especially sharpening your plane. Make it sharp, slightly round the corners, use a shallow setting, work methodically, and you won't have marks. Also, you need to check whether the sole of your plane is flat. 

Good on you for keeping practicing and wanting to learn!

video_title: The Most Powerful Laser Diode? NEJE Master 2S Plus A40640 Laser
comment_text: There are a couple ways to get a stable focus, either eyeballing it or drawing lines on an inclined plane (too much to go in to here--search Youtube).  But once you find the height, measure it with calipers.  Then make a block that height--in my case, I 3D printed a simple rectangular block, was able to get within 0.05mm of the desired height, I think.  Then, if you want to etch, place your block on top of the etching surface, and let the laser module rest on the block while tightening.  If you want to burn, set your block on the empty honeycomb (or whatever sacrificial surface), and let the module rest on the block while tightening--remove the block and insert your material to burn.  This puts the focal length at the bottom of the material.  Note, this only works for up to a few millimeters of material.

video_title: What Can a $500 CNC Do? Genmitsu 3020 Pro Max
comment_text: You are having problems with aluminium because you are not using the correct type of end mill. If the mill is chocking up use an end mill with more flutes or a higher rotation speed. Also you need mills with cutting geometry specifically for soft metals like aluminium and brass on low powered machines like this. If you had tried this with brass it would have probably given even worse results because brass is so soft it tends to grab the cutter so definitely needs correct end mills with the correct geometry. Also a shorter end mill will help and repositioning the spindle higher up in the mount will produce less stresses in the z axis and gantry assemblies.

video_title: What Can a $500 CNC Do? Genmitsu 3020 Pro Max
comment_text:
I bought this 3020 in Nov 2021 strictly for aluminum cutting. I‚Äôve been using a competitors machine for over a decade and it works great. I was disappointed with this machine and had several issues. It will cut aluminum but not not very well. The 1/8‚Äù bit must be all the way in the shaft. (And to prevent milling the table it‚Äôs best to lower the Z axis to the lowest point and raise the spindle in the holder so the bit can‚Äôt reach the table.) But the spindle is just not rigid enough to handle the cutting, the length of the shaft allows slight flexing. And the spindle doesn‚Äôt have enough speed or torque. I found that even slowly cutting a 1‚Äù hole in 2mm aluminum with 9 passes was nail biting. It did cut the hole but was a struggle. The finished hole was a few thousands under size because the spindle rigidity was causing it to flex inward. And just drilling a 1/8‚Äù hole w the milling bit would sputter when reaching the bottom, and wallowed the hole almost every time. So to fix both issues I hack sawed the spindle holder (another problem-only a 55mm spindle fits), and mounted a $70 rotozip (600W 30K RPM) with metal strapping. Now it mills, drills, and cuts much better. Note that after less than 10 hours the 300W spindle stopped working.

The other issue I had was that most all of the USB software I tried wouldn‚Äôt run a few commands of my existing gcode. Also, it was essential that I could stop and start the gcode from any gcode line, and couldn‚Äôt do it! So, to get around those problems I abandoned the USB controller and bought a parallel stepper driver and use LinuxCNC (or Mach2).

Overall it‚Äôs a nice little machine but wouldn‚Äôt recommend for aluminum unless your into mods.

comment_text:
I was also split between the LM3 and D1. After watching every review I could find and then reading purchased reviews I decided that the Ortur was the way to go for me. First, the performance seemed to be slightly better when engraving and second but more importantly were the customer service oriented ratings. There seemed to be a trend towards a lack of customer service with xTool lately. I know there is a lot of turmoil going on in China right now so this is probably a temporary thing. Lastly, Amazon had a flash sale on the LM3 the other day making it $595 so I jumped on it. That left more money for accessories which we'll need to run these at there best. Just my 2 cents... 

Cheers,
Greg

video_title: Top Laser Engravers and Cutters to Get in 2022
comment_text: Engraving DPI is hugely important.  While I know 1200 DPI on a diode or fiber is doable, they are mainly marking machines (not cutting).  When I compared machines, I asked specifically about DPI ... they all report higher numbers than to be expected AND/or skipped around an answer ... their website numbers cannot be trusted.  The newer gen. machines have better motors than the 4+ yr old designs and can consistently do +800dpi, like the 2 co2 machines you mentioned.  There are more economy options that can perform, and there are more DIY coolers that aren't messy nor expensive.  I have a BOSS 70W and can cut/engrave basically anything I desire.  but it's older and doesn't have the newer motors (so the effective DPI is about 1/2 of the newer machines with the smallest focal lens), but it can be upgraded.  If it's a hobby, speed isn't as important ... precision is.  i would never spend less than $3k on any laser, period.  People ask when i give them stuff i make: " You did what?"  i say:"yes, I'm a Jedi, I cut stuff with light".  Diodes imo don't count.  I've used over 36 types of materials .. and my co2 hasn't failed me yet.

video_title: Better and Cheaper than Glowforge?  Gweike Cloud Laser Review
comment_text:
If you're spending 4-7 grand on a machine, the learning curve is insignificant.  Once you've learnt it, you don't keep learning it.  What does matter, is the day to day experience of using it once you've climbed that curve.  For example. I have a great bean-to-cup coffee machine.  It makes great coffee, and I can tweak it to my heart's content, even though it's a clunky interface.  What is unforgiveable, is that every single time I turn it on, I have to wait for it to go through a cleaning cycle.  I can't put my cup under the brew head until it's finished, or it will fill with dirty water, so I can't just press a button and let it do its stuff.  Before it turns off, it cleans itself again.  It cleans itself so often, I have to refill the water really often, and empty the drip tray just as often.  I have another, much less fancy, less refined machine that I bought when the other broke down.  I can press the power button, and twenty seconds later press the button to brew the coffee, and a minute later I'm drinking espresso.  It's not quite as good at making my perfect coffee, but it's pretty good, it's harder to dial it in, it's noisier, and nothing like as polished, but in daily use it's so much more user friendly that I prefer it to my other machine.
For laser cutters, if you have to spend a couple of minutes getting the focus just right, or you need several trial runs to set the power/speed for each job, it doesn't matter how easy to learn it is, it's going to get tiresome pretty quickly.  Another machine might be hard to learn at first, you might need to build up a database of materials and power/speeds, but if, after doing that, all you have to do is insert the stock and press start, and know that it'll do the same good job every time, that machine will win every time.

video_title: Better and Cheaper than Glowforge?  Gweike Cloud Laser Review
comment_text:
This long comment is in no way criticising  this video. It is ,hopefully, adding more techincal colour to this already informative video.

 Any 50 watt tube will be 1000mmm long and 50mm diameter. 50 watts is the max power test spec. NOT what you can use. This will be an 800mm long 40 watt tube  that will fit iinsde the 970mm wide case. 50 watts is marketeing speak. There are major issues with fume extraction and Gweike have issued a couple of upgrades (check out their videos). You need air FLOW through the  machine to extract fumes. You cannot get FLOW through a closed box like the Glowforge and the little grill on the Gweike is an inadequate  concession to this requirement of physics. 
600mm/s is a meaningless marketing spec if you dont have the power to damnage material at that speed . Every different type of wood or material has a different damage threshold so the MDF used in this test  requires a critical level light  INTENSITY for a certain EXPOSURE time to damage it. The fixed INTENSITY of a candle flame will damage your hand if you pass it through the flame slow enough.......that demonstates what exposure time means... That is the whole  principle of engraving. The Gweike  has a typical 2" lens but you can make the candle beam more intense  because Gweike supply a shorter 1.5" lens. and that means faster engraving .....but poorer cutting. Not an option on the Glowforge. 

 The overtavel at the end of each scan depende on the speed you choose to scan at. If you decide to run at 300mm/s (as per the video)  then the overtravel  is a fixed non-engraving event.  In this case the Gweike  is running at 250dpi so there are also 250 scans  per inch of image that is 500 non-engraving events per inch. The Glowforge has 450 non engraving events per inch. So there is MORE wasted time on the Gweike but it still engraves quicker becuse of its shorter overtravel (faster acceleration.)  Because the Gweike machine can run with the native Ruida software (RDWorks) or Lightburn. you have the opportunity to crank up the acceleration (software controlled) and make the Gweike run light years faster than the  "you cant touch anything" Glowforge.

Speed is meaningless for cutting, it always has to be done slowly, maybe 10 to 20mm/s would be typical  depending on material and thickness.. Neither machine is setup with  a cutting  configuration where the nozzle would  be close to the work. Thus any air assist is only protecting the lens and not making cutting more efficient. These are essentially engraving machines that can cut inefficiently.  Look at all the brown fume depositions around the cuts., that means  air  assist will do a great job of painting your engravings with this tarry residue.   

Cutting should always be done with a single pass, which CO2 lasers can do easily because they operae on a totally different wavelength to diode laserswhich for many physics reasons are very inefficient at cutting and require multiple passes.

 Auto focus is a big problem. A lens will be sold with a fixed focal length. But that focal length does NOT apply to lasers.That lens will work as specified if you put it into a telescope or camera where you are focusing an IMAGE with normal random non-coherent light. A laser beam si totally different and there is no IMAGING involved .  the aim is to focus light INTENSITY. If you focus a lens to cut efficiently at 10mm/s  it is certain that the best focal distance will be at least 1mm different to the manufacturer's fixed focus. Now try engraving at 400mm/s and the best focus (thinnest line) will be 2 or 3mm different.. The best focus also depends on the material being used. So power, speed and material can all affect the optimal INTENSITY focal point. So how can auto focus take all these factors into account? Thus the less sophisticated motor driven (software controlled) focus of the Gweike allows you to take thes various parameters into account  and lets YOU select the best focus  when you understand a bit more about the peculiarities of laser technology.

$50/month to ACCESS a machine that you may have already paid $5000 for  seems  scam that no one would ever fall for.   Hmmmm.  Ease of use?. I can remember when I was 5,  I probably had little or no technical ability. This machine would have been a great techno toy where I could make things happen with little or no knowledge of the technology. As a 5 year old it would have still required my dad to set it up before I could "play" with it.. This is a well presented video  but he and I  cant unlearn knowledge,  so making a  "an ease of use" judgment is very difficult. Where is the baseline?

As a business machine for making money the Gwieke wins hands down. Its faster (and, with knowledge, can be made even faster),  greater flexibility, much lower price. no forced rental of software and  no need for an internet connection. It also allows you to make mistakes and learn about laser technology in the process, so that  you are prepared for your jump up to a bigger more powerful machine.  Glowforge is a closed box where you have purposely been excluded from learning about laser technology. Its a great business model .


Final technical note. 100%power ?  The tube %power is not really watts. This is glass tube technology and the tube manufacturer specifies the safe  MAXIMUM current allowed to flow through the tube. The tube watts is determined by the current flow. For a 40 watt tube  the max RUNNING current you can use will be 18mA for a 40 watt tube and  19mA for a 45 watt tube (Do I believe Glowforge is 45 watts?  Note the tube dimensions and check on any tube manufacturers website). It is possible to set the high voltage power supply so that 100%power  does not exceed  these limits. This  protects the tube and give it 4 years or more life. I belive the Gweike has an ammeter fitted that allows you to check this.  Glowforge?  I think not.   Exceeding these limits through lack of knowledge  could be expensive and ruin your tube within a year. The mA current flow and watts output are not related linearly   so for example  for your 18mA  max current you will get 40 watts output  but at 1/3 of the current flow (6ma) you will be expecting 33%power ie13 watts.  Sadly no,  because the relationship is non-linear you will probably be delivering 20 or evern 25 watts. The % power applies to current flow through your tube and NOT watts.   50% power is not 20 watts.
