video_title: Better and Cheaper than Glowforge?  Gweike Cloud Laser Review
comment_text: I bought a gweike cloud pro and after setting up it didn't work- spent several hours overnight online with China only to have them tell me I needed a new button (on/off switch) it took over 2 weeks and cost me almost $30 in import fees- so back online overnight and got the button to work - tried the software and it wouldn't cut- engraved but did not cut- went step by step with the engineer online (using ding talk- like what's app- back and forth) he would send me something to try and I would try it and film it- let hi into my computer remotely- which is scary and feels like an invasion of privacy- still didn't work- so then we started to take things apart- pretty much took the whole machine apart and never got down to the problem- I used multimeters to test power supply- added metal to see if it was a connection that needed soldering- we went back and forth for about 9 hours the first night and 8 the next- while the engineer tried hard we did not get it to work and by then I had enough- my machine was in pieces- I am not sure it would have gone back together properly- so I asked for a refund or replacement- as they had nothing in stock I was given a refund ( Don't even ask about the nightmare to ship it back to them)  I might have just gotten a lemon but if you join the Facebook group you will see others that had a problem---In the end I am happy to have dodged a bullet and gotten a refund- I am now the proud owner of a thunder laser!

video_title: 3 HUGE Upgrades in the xTool D1 Pro!
comment_text: A 20W diode laser ALREADY exceeds the capability of 40-50W CO2 machines on cutting. That is because of the smaller dot size. Typical CO2 machines will have a dot size of .1mm to .15mm diameter compared to the dot size of .08mm x .1mm on the diode machines. A smaller dot size means the power is concentrated more. You will NOT be cutting 10mm plywood in a single pass on a 50W CO2 machine (I have one). Also, engravings will not be as crisp, although the larger CO2 machines offer faster engraving output from better rails and more powerful stepper motors.

video_title: Should you upgrade a budget laser cutter?
comment_text: My first laser was a K40, and it did well.  I upgraded to a XM-1060 100 watt Reci tube laser ONLY because of the bed size, and more power to cut in one pass .. I use LightBurn on the Xm-1060.   I make artistic wood boxes, so this worked well for that.   K40 did etch glass, stone, cut leather and wood, and engraved fairly decently...  The only upgrades I did was a better exhaust, diamond grill bed and a new Lens ..  My son owns a Glowforge.  He doesn't use it 3% of what I use my Xm-1060 or even the K40!  I think the K40 with the dsp, exhaust, mirror, lense and new controller ( with Lightburn ) is all you need for more than casual use of the K40.

video_title: Better and Cheaper than Glowforge?  Gweike Cloud Laser Review
comment_text: Glowforge was my introduction into the laser world (purchased through their original Kickstarter campaign in 2016), and 7 laser purchases later, I still use three Glowforge's daily.  Luckily 90% of our products are flat acrylic, smaller pieces that the Glowforge can handle easily so as far as ease of use goes, we just keep at least two of them cranking out products daily.  We do love Lightburn when it comes to the larger 150W CO2 we use for our big stuff, rotary, etc. as well as our new Fiber laser (thank god for Lightburn Galvo) so we can see how both situations bring value to your business.  Being an early Glowforge adopter, we paid half the price for both of our Basics and our Pro, so I'm not sure if I would choose Glowforge now at their current price point, but I really do love the cameras, auto-focus, and small footprint.  And their customer service has been other-worldly as well (several replacements (not necessarily their fault), overnight parts delivery, you name it).

video_title: Better and Cheaper than Glowforge?  Gweike Cloud Laser Review
comment_text:
By not including much about the pass through you are missing most of what makes the Glowforge pro better. Otherwise your G-machine is far more comparable to the Glowforge machines in the same price bracket. Instead of he 14 inch height of the G-machine the Pro can use material as big as you can fit in the house, not only for large projects but I buy my material 48" long and use as much as I need  Yes the 40 watt machines are rated at less power, but Glowforge does not "overclock"their machines so they last longer than if they run at max power. As for premium, if someone is trying to make money right away premium  opens up thousands of free designs that they can legally sell right away so if you have a market. If you want to design in Inkscape you have less of an incentive, but I still find many conveniences that I  use instead of going back to Inkscape or Gimp and reloading. With the many free designs ( full disclosure a few of mine as well) there is also access to the entire Noun Project that does not allow commercial use of their designs, but Glowforge worked out a deal and they get some of that premium fee also. So if you do not want to learn Inkscape, Gimp or many of the more pricey options. The Glowforge app is av pretty good design tool that you can even use on your tablet or phone. 

On another point, once the cur is loaded on to the machine there is no internet needed, so if the internet goes out while it is cutting it will not affect the machine. Unfortunately you cannot keep running that file again, though many have suggested it. Which brings up another point. There is a great deal of hands on connection that takes place over time. There are many complaints that connecting to support is more time consuming  than they like, but the volume is huge and it may take a bit, but the final result is far better than my abilities to interact with any other company.

video_title: Better and Cheaper than Glowforge?  Gweike Cloud Laser Review
comment_text:
Have a gweikecloud myself and love it. Did a few basic vids on my channel. I rep the GC hard whenever someone wants a desktop class laser. 

Dumped my prior Atomstack X7. Did not get the GF due to 1. closed system in both software and hardware and 2. price. If anyone is looking for other users of the GC, their facebook group(s) is your best place. They have like 3 facebook groups and it is confusing but join them all. You will find me and many others on there who love the GC.

comments to the video:
-gweikeclouds hinges are horrible unless you open it all the way (not sure how the GF is). better if the hinges hold at any angle. 
-passthrough is easy. just stick a magnet or something metal where the sensor is. but unfortunately fumes will escape.
-air compressor indeed is external on the GC but that means you can swap it to whatever you want. on GF its not upgradeable.

And yes, a big con is gweikes marketing. case and point you mention "autofocus." something is lost in translation there. They also make this mistake marketing the air assist. Heck a big con is indeed this overseas translation thing. While tech support is VERY responsive (you get assigned to like 7 tech people through an app after the purchase of the machine) sometimes small details can be lost in translation. Is that worth paying the thousands for a GF over the GC? nah. its not THAT bad but just a heads up from me to whoever looking to buy a GC.

Also i should mention for cost of the GC, it CAN get even cheaper as Gweike runs events here and there where you can get cash that brings down your initial purchase cost.

video_title: What Can a $500 CNC Do? Genmitsu 3020 Pro Max
comment_text:
This is obviously a HUGE improvement over the 3018, but still with a couple of weak spots; staying within a target price point always results in compromise.
** The linear rails on the X-axis are great, so... why not the Y-axis? (Yeah, I know, PRICE!).
** The spindle is still not good enough.  It is still just a cheap motor with the collet assembly held on with a grub-screw (or 2?).  This is a guaranteed source of chatter.
** The gantry does not move, so extra mass and strength is good here. (Apart from freight costs.)  Owners should add horizontal stiffening across the back, which would help in your "Pull on the toolbit" test.
** The cable-management is disgusting!... I am polite enough to assume this is not because you took shortcuts in the assembly!   :o)
This is a really useful video, thanks.   Liked & Subscribed.

video_title: What Can a $500 CNC Do? Genmitsu 3020 Pro Max
comment_text:
This was a very helpful video!  I would love to ask you what is the machine that you would get, similar travels on the axes with more on the z if possible, that can mill aluminum without serious compromise.  

Since aluminum likes to mess with us with it being gummy let's machine the gummiest aluminum - is that 6061 - if not please just specify and let's make say a motor mount plate.  So a square shape, say 3"x3" by 3/8 or 1/2" when finished with a bunch of holes punched through for through bolts, some holes to be tapped, 

Lets also mill a pattern into the face of this square of aluminum that is say a 2" square shape that is 1/4" wide square track that we are ending with. The feature is also a finished depth of 1/4".  

So if we are using proper feeds and speeds from the machinists handbook or other proper sources what is the most depth we can take on each pass say even on your typical industrial heavy duty vertical milling machine.  That sets our target or best possible case, then can you answer in your opinion which brand machine in these low dollar tiers do you think can actually come close to this level of performance.

Last but not least this machine needs to be capable of true 3d milling into aluminum. Lets say we are going to mill a ball shape where we have a semi-circle full round shape the diameter of the circle is 3" and the height at the center of the shape is also 3" - so we are getting what would look like a bandsaw slice through part of a pool ball cut in half,   Which machine can get great surface finishes and also do the work in a reasonable amount of time.  I am assuming that if a machine could make this 3d feature then it could likely make most features that i would ever need it to.  Please let me know if this is a poor assumption.


This whole CNC market has so many machines that could never hope to do this work which is fairly basic work for sure.  And I know that this was a little bit to read but I am hoping those of you with knowledge and experience will simply be able to just snap your fingers and say - yea, get a "THIS BRAND" and get "MODEL ABC123", they are great!  

Oh damn, we can't forget about cost, I would ask 2 things for cost.  1 - can you do this for under $1000?  How about for under $800 and wow if we can you can do this for $500.  

I have no idea what to expect so I hope that there is some feedback and all of it is going to be greatly appreciated.  Cheers!

video_title: It's 48x FASTER than a Diode Laser! 3PLASERS EM-Smart 20W MOPA Laser Review
comment_text:
Since MOPA is better for plastics, I'm curious how well a small, simple machine like this would do with PCB prototyping or small scale manufacturing. It wouldn't be too difficult to have a multi-material profile, just switch frequency and amplitude within a certain set of lines in the code. 'Etching' a PCB would be such a great alternative to the typical developing methods, as even some of the newer prototyping methods, like using a photoresist PCB blank on the LCD of an MSLA printer, still require developing in chemicals. If this could not only etch the traces, but also etch the board for proper marking, I don't see why this couldn't be a viable alternative to cheap board manufacturing. Stemming from this, I'm curious how well this kind of laser handles various solder masks, say if someone wanted to mask a whole board then etch the masking off the pads, instead of more typical processes; most PCB software already separate pads and traces, so technically you'd already have a file for just pads, with the proper settings you could potentially etch the solder mask but not the copper pad underneath. 

If it works out, something like this could be great for maker spaces, assuming someone had already gone through the calibrations for specific materials, thicknesses, etc. Even as a hobbyist or small business, a machine like this would be amazing for prototyping and small production runs.

comment_text:
I reached out to Xtool customer support for a D1 & accessories since I wanted to figure out if I need to pay import duty & VAT. 

They don't seem to be serious about EU law. No clarity on where they ship from. As an EU citizen, I have the right to know. 

As per EU Standard, the seller needs to tell the customer where its dispatched when placing an order, VAT, etc. If I ask about VAT, the Xtool customer support personnel is giving an inclusive response.  What I understood is partly they want to ship from the EU & partly from outside the EU. 

There is a tax obligation, depending on where they fulfill from. This needs to be clear when placing the order, if they ship from the EU, they pay VAT in one of the EU countries where you ship from. Otherwise, it's an export order, either they pay if you have IOSS registration or I need to pay on import extra cost to me. 

You are mixing up, and dogging after the initial response.  Maybe Xtool is good, but not possible to buy from with in EU.  After a week of chatting with them, now I am looking into some other brand.

video_title: The Best Laser Cutter for any Budget?
comment_text:
Interesting video, thanks for sharing your thoughts on lasers. I'm very surprised you picked Glowforge above all other desktop lasers. 

Having used both the Glowforge and others, the only benefit to Glowforge is ease of getting started.  The native Glowforge software is a bit easier to use, but it is also feature poor. They also hobble the software unless you pay a monthly subscription fee. 

Other drawbacks include - cleaning the Glowforge is more difficult, and the laser is underpowered for the price. Most importantly, and most hidden from the customer, - their support is weak at best; they are slow to respond to issues, if they ever do; and they don't really sell key replacement parts for wear and tear, instead they want you to ship your machine back and purchase a refurbished device for all but the smallest issues. 

Oh, and  you have to upload your designs to their cloud based service, meaning you can't print if your internet is offline and they can monitor what you print on your machine.

video_title: Is this feature worth $2400?  The Snapmaker 2.0 Rotary
comment_text:
10:18  Yeah, Enclosure (Which imo is kind of required for the laser) + Rotary + Main Machine is quite expensive.

I don‚Äôt know where i stand on it.  From what I‚Äôve seen it‚Äôs a good machine.  I also love the modular design, and sealed parts with rugged cables.

My main complaint is that it‚Äôs not open source, granted they have fears of copycats i guess?  Maybe they could do something like open source the last generation each time they make a new one?

I‚Äôm excited to see the one in it‚Äôs printing, because a locked down extruder/nozzle ecosystem is a concern i have not knowing much about this.

Also selling ‚Äútoolplates‚Äù so you could make a drag knife (or knife + servos for turning with the cut), or marker, or even EDM module would be really cool.  I think one channel has made their own pen  holder for the snapmaker.  Open Sourcing the standard could help toolhead development too.

I guess in conclusion if they could open source it, and/or get the cost of the rotary+enclosure+machine down to maybe 1,000-1,500 USD or so it would be top tier of ‚Äúfirst 3d printer‚Äù category, not just ‚Äúbest all in one machine‚Äù!  But as of now that all in one aspect is it‚Äôs only real plus i guess.

video_title: The Most Powerful Laser Diode? NEJE Master 2S Plus A40640 Laser
comment_text: "15 watt" laser? This is true. The laser manufacturers are taking the idea of running electronics at a lower power to lengthen their lives. GE used to do that with incandescent lifebulbs - they would manufacture the bulbs to run at 130v AC so that when we used them at normal household voltage (110-120) the bulbs would last a lot longer than typical bulbs. So NEJE is doing the same with their modules - building them with 15 watt, but driving them to produce 10.5 -11 watt output. So even if you run them at 100% for long projects, the laser will still continue to produce full power and have a decent lifespan. I have been reading how a few laser users are finding out that their lesser well-designed lasers would die soon after a project that required their lasers to run at 100% for an extended period of time. This is why NEJE, Atomstack and  other laser manufacturers are doing this "underpowering" their laser modules to extend their lives. They use 7.5 watt laser diodes and only force them to deliver 5 Watts. The dual diodes are 7.5 diodes x2, each powered to produce about 5.5 Watts each to result in a 10-12 watt laser, depending on the manufacturer. These NEW modules are typically rated with 20, 000 hour life spans.

video_title: How Good is this Thing? Snapmaker 2.0 Laser Module Review
comment_text:
I‚Äôve been using my T250 for about a month now. I‚Äôve found it to be a way better printer than my Ender 3 V2, easy to set up, easy to calibrate and much more even bed heating. I‚Äôve found it way easier to get consistent layering and I haven‚Äôt had a print come loose yet. Once you get the work flow down swapping between modes is about 5 minutes work. Laser works well for engraving and cuts 2mm birch,  it it‚Äôs slow. Luban works well very well if you‚Äôre just doing something straight forward. 

My assessment, it‚Äôs much easier to get started, get making and get consistent results with this than my Ender. I enjoy using the snapmaker and feel like I get to focus on the project not the machine. My first month with the ender was an endless series of failed prints, great learning experience but at times quite discouraging. First time I booted up the SM, it auto calibrated, I dropped the print head 0.5mm, hit print and got a perfect print of a model I was still failing to get on the Ender after a half dozen attempts.

For the hardcore 3D printers out there perhaps the bang for the buck is low, for the rest of us this is great

video_title: How Good is this Thing? Snapmaker 2.0 Laser Module Review
comment_text:
I have one. I hate it, and I truly wish I had bought a D1, cheap CNC, and upgraded a few of my enders. Would have saved me a lot of time and money. 

So within a week of opening the machine, I reached out to Snapmaker for support concerning the laser function. Turns out the guy I got stuck with didn't know what he was talking about. He told me it was broken, and I was then jacked around for 3 months before they stopped replying at all. 3 months later (6 months in total) They reach back out to me concerning a negative review I left on a third party site.  I used their contact to start trying to get help from them again, only to find out the problem I originally had is a limitation of the machine itself. Camera capture cannot accurately capture tall items  (3-4" tall) for engraving. It just cuts out massive sections of the image. So 6 months, countless hours of time, and countless materials wasted trying to fix a machine that they said was broken... that wasn't. 

They also removed my negative review from their site, and tried to bribe me into taking down my third party site review. 

I did end up getting a 50% refund, but that was because I was prepared to dispute the charges with Paypal. It's an ok, non upgradeable 3D printer. It's not a Prusa, or even an Ender. Haven't had a chance to play with the CNC yet, as the machine is noisy enough on its own. 

My review stands, and I'll continue to tell everyone about my experiences. The machine is meh, and the support is crap.

comment_text:
Hi Brandon, I recently picked up the Neje A40640 and have been working on calibrating it for a few weeks - I'm a total n00b and really appreciate your videos!

When digging a bit deeper into the reference documentation - I noticed that this module has a variable focal distance - the lens actually rotates. In the Neje wiki documentation I've found that they recommend setting it at a focal distance of about 33mm for engraving and about 55mm for cutting (18mm ply?!?).  You have to unscrew the lens about 7 full rotations from it's fully 'closed' or seated position against the upper housing for engraving but it definitely produces a finer spot. 

My USB microscope doesn't have a measurement tool but from my very rough estimate, it looks like I can get a line width of around .12 when setup for the 'engraving'  focal distance.

I'm sure folks would appreciate your more seasoned look at it - especially as you call it out as having a bigger dot width, which may not be entirely accurate given the configuration options. 

I hope this observation comes across in the most positive light,  I really appreciate all videos and your calibration methods - super helpful for someone new to the technology! Keep up the great work!!

video_title: Can This Laser Beat the Competition? Sculpfun S9 Laser Review
comment_text: Soo I have an Atomstack A5pro which is about the same power 5,5W. These diode laser are great TOYS yes toys... they are great sweet toys to learn laser cutting to use Lightburn but they are absolutely unusable to anything serious. After half year I bought a 50W CO2 laser and the difference is DAY and NIGHT. If you want to cut out anything complicated with a diode laser you have to wait 2-3 hours... the CO2 is exactly 10X faster which is a LOT. Without air assist and what is even more important without smoke sucking!!!!  People cannot imagine how much smoke these machines generate, you cannot stay in the same room if you are cutting wood or plastic for longer times..... Soo please people don't believe anybody if you really want to cut than save up for a CO2 machine. (Yes I know it cost 6-7X more but it worth it) These diode lasers are a waist of money... and no they will not be stronger the two diode versions are quite expensive with 10W makes the CO2 almost cheap. Only one thing which is slightly better with the diode laser is the the kerf (cutting width) is slightly smaller (but also not circular but like rectangle). Think long term go with CO2...

video_title: Testing the OM Tech K40 Laser
comment_text:
Just FYI.
Don't run the ground lug to a different ground than what your source of power is using, it is dangerous.

NEC wants an effective ground fault path for ground faults, the Dirt or a rod in the Dirt is not an effective ground fault path. 

An example would be if the metal frame became energized, the dirt has too high of resistance to return the voltage to it's source, in this scenario you would get shocked if you touched it.

A rod in the dirt is only good at discharging static or lightning.

That is why the ground is tied to the neutral in your electrical panel.

If the case becomes energized it will take the path of least resistance back to source through the ground wire which would cause the circuit breaker to become overloaded and open.

That's how the ground wire works. It's an effective ground fault path back to the  source, utility.
Static and lightning discharging back it's source, Earth through the ground rod.

Thanks for the awesome video üëç

In the video you mention air assist, or lack thereof, on diode lasers, but as a lacking safety feature for putting out fires.. Is the use of air assis that different in the two types? video_title: Should You Buy a Glowforge?
comment_text:
I like the concept that Glowforge has, the self contained air assist and cooling is very nice. What I don't like is the software being online. If the company folds you are out of
luck and if the Internet goes down while you are just about to finish off a big job then you are forced to wait.  My son in-law just purchased an OMTech 80Watt laser for about

comment_text: I think you put the bottoms wrong and that's why you can't use the whole table area. Look carefully. These lower two aluminum plates, on one is attached the motor, on the other the handle for rotation. They have to be turned upside down, the protruding things on these aluminum plates are actually the legs of the machine and they have to be down. If you turn these parts upside down, the table will be able to pass over them and have more space for movement.

video_title: The Best Laser Cutter for any Budget?
comment_text:
I custom built ours for our small business, but I also have an engineering background and several years experience with 3d printers and motion systems including modifying firmware..  It is a 7W diode that I will be upgrading to 10W soon on a approximately 5 ft x 5 ft frame (about 1400mm squared actual work space).  My other half and sister in law do a lot of sewn products for people, and being able to laser cut when you need 50 of the same pattern cut at a time is a huge timesaver.  It cost me around $1000 in parts to build plus a lot of time, but even a diode unit that large would be a few thousand dollars minimum.  I could have dropped that price by 3d printing more parts instead of using aluminum for 99% of the machine.

I recognize that is not a good option for most people though.

video_title: Fusion 360 - Did Autodesk just kill the FREE Version?
comment_text:
I think the changes are a big negative for hobby users or those teaching themselves or in the pre-start-up phase.

They made 3 axis projects take a lot longer by removing rapids. A 3-hour project will now take 12 hours which is huge if you have to stand watching the machine (as most hobby users do). Not to mention the extra power usage...

They made 4 and 5 axis hobby cnc machines useless by removing that functionality completely. This limits what you can make regardless if it's a one-off hobby job or full production. 

Manual tool changes have been made needlessly arduous as they now require a whole new operation.

They could have achieved the stated goal by simply limiting the hobby version to only posting to Mach 3 and Linuxcnc which no commercial VMCs use. 

Most of what they removed has nothing to do with commercial operations. It looks more aimed at forcing hobby users to pay for expensive subscriptions for the small handful of personal projects they do.

video_title: The ALMOST perfect laser: The xTool S1 Laser Review
comment_text:
I really enjoy your channel, but a factor none of the review channels seem to discuss is the VERY short service life for xTool products. As recently as 9 months ago, xTool was heavily promoting their D1 and D1 Pro lasers, yet if one visits their site now, ALL of the replacement parts are "out of stock", and none of the laser heads can be replaced, with the exception of the $1,200 40w head for the D1 Pro.

So if your machine breaks, be aware you cannot get parts to repair it. This seems to be true for all xTool products, and I think a 2 year (maximum) service life is preposterous for a tool at this price-point.

video_title: Laser Companies are Lying to You
comment_text: I like the idea of getting a laser cutter/engraver, but I am wholly against getting one without a full enclosure that's fully opaque to the laser frequency the machine uses. Sure you can wear goggles and protect yourself, but if there's any more than zero chance that someone else could walk in while it's running, no matter how small, then I'm unwilling to accept the risk of inadvertently causing permanent eye damage to them. Class 4 lasers are nothing to play with; even just seeing the spot they make can cause eye damage before the signal reaches the brain.

video_title: Laser Companies are Lying to You
comment_text:
I find it crazy that people buy into the unshielded lasers expecting anything good to come of it. The only laser cutter/engraver I have experience with was a massive unit with full shielding and multiple warning stickers about the dangers of laser radiation. These unshielded units are either not powerful enough to do what they advertise, or they are dangerously leaking radiation into your surroundings and you should probably discontinue using it. Generally, a laser above 5mw is enough to cause eye damage if directly shone into your eyes, and lasers above around the 250mw range can cause temporary eye damage indirectly in large exposure. Above 500mw, the damage is permanant. 

These units are often claiming their lasers are "40W", which is 80 times the limit for permanent eye damage. This makes the lasers about 9 times more dangerous to handle for the end user. At this level, indirectly viewing the beam or the landing point of the beam will damage your eyes, likely permanantly. The wave length of the laser doesn't change much about the danger to your eye sight, as even undetectable in the UV and IR wave lengths will blind you. Non-visable-light-based lasers (say that 5 times fast) are often more dangerous as you don't even have any reflexes to mitigate the damage. Visable light lasers will cause your eye to reflexively close, which limits the exposure time and chance of blindness. IR and UV wavelengths don't trigger this response, so you won't know anything is wrong until your eye starts hurting which means the exposure time is already exceeding three times the normal amount for visable light, if not more so. Don't cheap out on laser tech, it's dangerous.

You left out a couple of hugely important categories... 1.  "Can you buy parts?"  

At least one of those machines will not sell you parts, when your tube gets weak you have to ship it back to the manufacturer and they give you a coupon for a discount on a supposed "Refurbished" machine.   So to replace your tube cost you a few thousand dollars, or a bearing, or any other part you can't get from somewhere else.

2. One thing I that wasn't clear in the "Connectivity" section, which machines force you to be connected to their cloud before they let you use it?  That is a HUGE deal breaker for me.  If the internet, or your router, or their server, is down so is your laser???  Not going to happen.  

If a company has that much control over whether or not you can use your machine that will eventually come around to screw you, guaranteed.  At some point that company is going to want you to pay for it's cloud, meaning a new monthly subscription service.  At any time that company could go out of business making your laser a super expensive paper weight.  Look at how many Youtube vids are out there highlighting how their projects were delayed, or completely ruined because Adobe's servers crashed so Premier locked up.  

Both of these issues make a huge difference in which lasers are usable/affordable.

video_title: Laser Companies are Lying to You
comment_text:
compare dc power supplies from the US and China. An American two watt power supply is the size of a red brick and has 16 gauge output wires. The Chinese 2 watt power supply is the size of an ice cube and has 30 gauge wires

compare ac motors from the US and China. An American 1 hp motor is a load for a guy who is called Lurch and Worf and Sasquatch by strangers. you wear steel toed boots when you have to lift it. A Chinese 1 hp motor can be handled by a 12 year old.

I wear 10 1/2 EE Red wings. I wear 11 Chinese boots. I can buy Red Wings through the mail. I buy Chinese footwear in a shoe store.

Chinese amps are not American amps. Chinese watts are not American watts. ergo, Chinese facts are not American facts. Adjust expectations accordingly.

comment_text:
I was glad to see that you gave Glowforge a 1 star for software, but you didn't really say why.  The reason is because glowforge does not run gcode, it does not and cannot accept gcode, so it's impossible for any software to interface with it.  Everything has to go through their website.  Also you have to pay a monthly fee to do anything but the very basics with their software.  If you want to cut a square, for example, through their software, that is considered a premium feature and you have to pay for that feature.

But glowforge does do passthrough nicely.
Also glowforge has some nice features that you've missed.  For example it detects if you cut anything that will create poison gas that will kill you.  An absolute must if you're going to put this in a classroom where a kid might be vinyl in the machine. That feature alone would make the glowforge the only option for many IMHO.

video_title: $2K Cheaper, 2X Better? - The Thunder Bolt Desktop Laser
comment_text: I would say the #1 factor beyond the price point is knowing ahead of time what you plan on doing with this, or any, laser to make money.  If you think you are going to laser some cool images on a piece of wood and ever get your money back...think again.  Every Tom, Dick, and Harry is out there trying to do the same exact thing.  The cheaper the entry level into business (and 5K is beyond cheap) the more people are going to be in your space and for that reason...you should really have an idea of how you are going to make a profit BEFORE you buy the laser.  This is way more important than the price differences between the laser.  You can come back from spending to much if you have a great idea.  You will not come back from getting a great deal on a laser if you have no idea how you are going to turn a profit.  Figure it out before you buy the laser....don't hope and pray you will just magically figure it all out after you get it.

video_title: Laser Companies are Lying to You
comment_text:
A great vid but just like the companies I feel you are understating the danger of an open enclosure a little bit. Fire is one things but a far more imminent danger from using a laser and wanting to see how it is cutting and engraving is being blinded for the rest of your life. 

Even a stray beam from a 5 watt laser is enough to turn your vision from stereoscopic to monoscopic and that'll happen a whole lot faster than starting a fire.

comment_text: If this had a 400x400 work area it would be great. I'd rather go with an XTool with a bigger work area and a home built enclosure. Enclosures are super-easy to make. You can just make a plywood box with a hinged lid. You seal it with caulk in the seams and weather stripping on the lid. And for air flow you put a PC fan on the side and a hose coming out the other side you vent to a window. To see you can add some plexiglass to the lid and/or sides. It may not look pretty but it works really well and is cheap.

comment_text: The wavelength in those lasers is comparable to the wavelength of light used during intraeye laser surgery. In other words, diode lasers go right past your cornea and start burning the inside of your eyes. CO2 lasers however view clear plastic and your corneas as opaque. Therefore, it's exceptionally easy to shield your eyes from CO2 lasers and basically impossible for diodes.

video_title: Laser Companies are Lying to You
comment_text:
i only buy the diodes, and about the best ive found readily available are 5W... nichia nubm08 or summink? can pulse them a bit harder, but yeah... continuous, without chilling  water cooled loops... 5W.

wavelengths matter... what transfers the most energy to the workpiece, ie, is absorbed the most readily by most surfaces versus reflected? blue? or IR? dont have a choice with diodes other than wimpy green... which is IR under the lens.

meh, diodes are cool but the aberration is annoying. beam correction is a hassle, and most dont do it. need a semi cylindrical or anamorphic prism setup... fiddly. if you want the precisest DOT possible rather than a line...

theres another thing about depth and its the focal length. a short beam obviously must have a steep convergence angle, with a wide dispersion cone beyond the focal point. you make conical cuts. a long focal length gives closer to a parallel beam.

in the end, you still get the same energy on the dot but the long focal length does have the head far away... more scatter, more wobble, more jitter and error amplification...

focusing to a dot then collimating is next to impossible as the AR surface coatings break down... the beam has too pretty well much cover the entire lens or yeah. smoke :)

played with combining.splitting prisms with three diodes but omfg, not worth it. take more passes.

i know theres an actual assembly but im a cheapskate. one day i might get a CO2...

Performance? I'll buy 2 more and it will still be cheaper than CO2.

comment_text: The word "comparable' doesn't mean 'equivalent'. So that's not specifically a lie since it's making a true statement, even though it's deceptive because people don't realize that words actually have multiple definitions and uses, and if only one use is literally true, then the statement isn't a lie. That being said, on principle I don't buy anything where the title is literally a lie designed to make me look, even if the item details look good because if they literally lie in the title, I can't trust any other claim they make.

comment_text:
Looks like this video was recommended to me a couple of years late but it's still relevant.  The factor that you didn't mention at all is likely the biggest factor to consider when making this decision... Serviceability.   While the K40 is obviously repairable, since it can be upgraded, it's my understanding that the Glowforge is not serviceable at all.  

Last year I was considering buying a used Glowforge and found dozens for sale.  Thinking that anything bought used would likely at least need a new tube I looked into the cost of parts and the tube.  Turns out you can't buy parts or repair the machine on your own.  If your tube, or any other part, goes out then the only option is to ship the machine back to Glowforge and they will give you a discount on buying a new one.  I couldn't find any other service information so I opted to not get one.  

It's a truly  horrible policy that makes the Glowforge seem more like a scam than a ligament machine.  I hope that I either missed something or they fix the way they treat their customers.

Good grief -- 40w -- good video, nice work as always -- I wish I had bought the X-tool.

Ortur issues  info below:

Well-Known Issues with Ortur Lasermaster 3: A Comprehensive Review

Issue 1: Ortur LM-3 Not Powering On
One of the most prevalent problems encountered by users of the Ortur Laser Master 3 is its failure to power on. This issue can stem from various factors, including a faulty power adapter, blown fuse, loose connections, malfunctioning laser module, or motherboard glitches. Notably, the Ortur LM-3 has faced criticism for having an underpowered "power brick." Despite seeking assistance for this issue, my attempts were met with silence. Subsequently, I discovered a suitable replacement on Amazon.

Issue 2: Inadequate Laser Engraving
When laser engravings fail to meet expectations, several causes might be at play. These include improper focus, uneven engraving area, or unsuitable materials for engraving.

Issue 3: Mid-Operation Halts
Frequent occurrences of the machine halting during operations can be attributed to loose connections, faulty motors, or software/firmware glitches. This issue has been highlighted extensively on YouTube.

Issue 4: Subpar Engraving Quality
Substandard engraving quality can arise due to incorrect settings, a dirty lens, or a malfunctioning laser module. To rectify this, adjustments in settings, proper lens maintenance, and considering the laser module's condition are recommended.

Issue 5: Smoke and Odor Production
During operation, the machine emitting smoke or strong odors might be a result of a dirty lens, improper settings, or insufficient ventilation. This concern is commonplace among lasers, particularly during cutting. Installing proper external ventilation and employing an enclosed setup are advised solutions.

Issue 6: Unusual Motor Noises
Motors emitting abnormal sounds during operation may be attributed to loose connections, inadequate lubrication, or faulty motors. Similar observations have been shared on YouTube. A common cause was Ortur's inadequate tightening of drive sprocket set screws, resulting in loosening.

Issue 7: SD Card Recognition Failure
When the machine fails to recognize an SD card, possible reasons include a faulty SD card, corrupted files, or firmware complications. Contacting Ortur for assistance may lead to unresponsiveness, as evidenced by my own experience.

Issue 8: Machine Freezing During Operation
Machine freezing mid-operation may stem from software/firmware glitches, motherboard issues, or communication problems between the machine and the computer. Establishing a reliable link between my Ortur LM-3 and my computer proved to be a major struggle. Despite weeks of effort and assistance from Ortur, I ultimately sold my brand-new machine at a loss due to this issue.

Issue 9: Inconsistent Engravings
Inconsistent engraving results might result from incorrect settings, a dirty lens, problematic materials, or a malfunctioning PWM (pulse width modulated) laser power controller. Obtaining assistance from Ortur for this issue was often challenging.

Lack of Customer Support and Service
In terms of customer service and support, Ortur falls significantly short. Despite purchasing their hardware, I received no aid when problems arose. Requests for help went unanswered, and defective parts were disregarded. Unfortunately, Ortur seems unwilling to invest in its customers' needs or satisfaction.

Personal Experience with Ortur LM-3
My excitement for the Ortur Laser Master 3's potential to enhance my workshop quickly turned to disappointment and frustration. Despite its promising appearance, I encountered only obstacles and minimal assistance from Ortur. Their lone response directed me elsewhere for help. Ultimately, after exhausting various resources without resolution, I was forced to sell the Ortur LM-3 at a substantial loss, leading to the demise of my aspirations.

An Urgent Recommendation
Given my ordeal, I strongly advise considering alternative options before investing in an Ortur product. It is my hope that you avoid supporting a company that displays such an evident lack of commitment to both product quality and 
customer service.

Parting Thoughts
I am not inclined to write negative reviews, but I felt compelled to share my experience as a cautionary tale for others. Thank you for taking the time to read my account, and I sincerely wish you success in your pursuit of a laser product that truly meets your expectations.

video_title: Top Laser Engravers and Cutters to Get in 2022
comment_text: The problem that I have with Atomstack (and various other companies) is that they lie outrageously about their laser power, advertising the power consumption of the unit rather than the optical output power (which is the only thing that is meaningful). Reputable companies (J-Tech Photonics and Gweike Cloud, for example) do not do this. Yes, Atomstack buries an optical output power deep in their text, but I wouldn't trust it to be accurate given how dishonest they are in the rest of their advertising (for example, 48W for the X40 MAX is **obvious** BS to anyone familiar with diode lasers). In my opinion, we should boycott all laser manufacturers that even mention the power consumption, given how much it misleads many buyers. And, I want to see them show the ACTUAL laser output power being measured with a power meter (again, J-Tech and Gweike Cloud do this).

+50% $ for an upgraded machine sounds great. 
+100% $ sounds justifiable if the quality/features are there.

I like that they're trying to make a more premium Chinese laser but I think it's an oversight to not at least include the features of the competitors that are less than half the price.

comment_text: Got my laser off eBay, 100W tube, 900x600 huge area, Autofocus, rotary axis, 900mm/s max speed in stock configuration. Paid $2000 delivered, earned probably $6000 with it already. All these machines that you test are just fancy toy machines for people who know nothing about technology really. Hardly upgradable too. That tiny area is probably barely going to cover needs of a housewife, and don't even get me started of how much these companies are charging hamsters for their K40 $300 equivalent toys. If I wanted to spend a $3000+ on a CO2 laser, I would just build a freaking servo driven 150W  1m2 monster. They way people waste money is just hilarious. I mean, same people buy carton sheds in usa for $500000, what can you expect from them after that lol. The only thing I truly hate about all industrial lasers is a very stupid controller and a software, RUIDA controllers absolutely suck and they are supposedly the best around, so everything else is even worse apparently. I'd love to have some opensource FW options to be able to tinker and add more features to industrial lasers.

video_title: Is Saving Hundreds Worth it?  The Atomstack X30 Laser Review
comment_text: I work with industrial flatbed lasers that cut up to 1 inch thick aluminum plate. I realize this far removed from the "hobbyist" spectrum, but I am awaiting the day that we have hobbyist level lasers that can cut sheet metal components that can be used in weldments.

video_title: Is Saving Hundreds Worth it?  The Atomstack X30 Laser Review
comment_text: Atomstack now also have an upgraded controller that you can use with LightBurn to control the air assist (on/off). I agree that handpad is useless. One thing I never see mentioned is diode laser life. My x20 has reduced in power by about a third (according to my cut tests) with only 10s of hours on it. It's not a dirty lens/lens protector or S30 setting issue. They have agreed for me to send it back (after copious amounts of poor and repetitive formulaic email support). On the whole I'm not impressed with the build quality. The focus adjustment is sloppy (the addon z-height adjuster requires moving the M2.5 tapped holes for a limit switch), my x-axis eccentric nut was over tightened at the factory which damaged the v-wheels and I had to replace them. The cable management is poor. My next laser is going to be the Roly 20 or 40W. The Roly10W build quality is amazing and their tech support is first class.

video_title: Why do these lasers cost so much?
comment_text: There are a HUGE difference when it comes to power and the way Thunder Laser USA advertises the tubes provided. A 100watt Thunder has 10-20% more power than a 100watt Omtech or similar laser. As a example if you buy a 100 watt co2 laser from most manufacturers the tube has a MAXIMUM output of 100 watts but you are only recommended running them at 90% of the advertised power. Thunder Laser USA sell 100watt lasers with a usable output of 100watts. They throttle the power back from (in my case) 118 watts maximum output and this allows you to set the power to 100% in lightburn and get a true 100watt output with no risk of damage to the tube.

video_title: Why do these lasers cost so much?
comment_text:
I remember commenting that you should check them out ages ago. Glad you finally got one!

There's two things that I would like to note - the doors require a key to open, which is annoying. All I need is a latch. I don't understand why the doors are keyed when the main lid isn't. 

The other issue is not having a guide that corresponds to the bounds of the cutting area. For example, you will see a ruler on the X and Y axis. You can push material up to it and know exactly where it is every time. Trotec and epilog both have ruler guides in some of their cutting tables.

Everyone's got a different workflow though. I personally use absolute coords 98% of the time. I can add items to existing sheets just by bringing up the file.

comment_text:
I'll admit, the features are great, but as usual, they are extremely overpriced for consumers.  Sadly, they are still using low quality laser tubes and mirrors. You are basically paying 2000$ for shipping software.  The cooling system is sub par, and being locked into their software to use the features is a gimmic.   If this company really wanted a consumer audience,  they would work with the popular sw companies to integrate the support they provide and also sell a product with better hardware.   This laser is being sent out in hopes to nab a few 1 off customers but geared at businesses that do not know better or want a mini laser farm.  Not including the software or time, an identical laser built with better quality parts would cost about 2k currently.   Yes it would not look as nice, but 3000$ extra just so you don't have to alignment your work is insane.  Also any business that would be using lasers, will definitely be concerned about time and ensure to align everything well to get the most bang for their buck.

In short... great idea, horrible price, wrong targeted market.

Use better hardware and reduce the price by 50% and then you will be in the right audience and market.

video_title: Is Glowforge Dead?  FLUX HEXA 60W Laser Review
comment_text:
While a top speed of 900mm/s sounds nice on paper, the weight of the head means that the accellerations are slow, which more often than not makes a bigger difference. The example engraving you showed wasn't nearly large enough to make use of the speed. That is, as soon as it gets to the engrave, it should already start slowing down. Now, to bypass that, there's the overscan area, which is this case is excessively large because it needs a long time to reverse that heavy head. 

Long story short; Top speeds are nice and all, but pretty meaningless without high accelerations to make use of it.

video_title: Better and Cheaper than Glowforge?  Gweike Cloud Laser Review
comment_text:
I would never go the Glowforge route for the same reason that I have never and will never go for iPhone over Samsung or Mac over PC. Apple are monopolists. That is to say, if you buy an Apple product you are buying into a closed ecosystem that does not allow for competition, meaning that whatever you need beyond the basic product itself, i.e., accessories, software, etc., can only be purchased from Apple at whatever price Apple dictates, take it or leave it.

Glowforge have obviously decided to emulate the Apple everything-in-house business model and for me their online-only obligatory subscription software model that excludes all other possibilities is a deal breaker, and that's before taking into account the fact that the product costs twice as much as the Gwieke. If I buy something, I own it _not_ it owns me.

video_title: 6 Mistakes Not to Make When Building a Farmhouse Table
comment_text: For those wondering how to stop Big Box from cupping...flip your boards over to what is going to be the bottom. Make sure all your boards fit together tight..clamp them tight..like you are doing a glue up..take your router and cut a 1/2  wide groove from side to side..NOT the length..stop about half way through the last board...go buy some rebar and use epoxy ...drop the rebar in deep enough so it's just below the surface..mix and pour in your epoxy...let set up.and dry...BAM ... done. We did this to a table we made using pine from HD..It's been outside for over 3 years...NO MOVEMENT..NO CUPPING..NO SPLITTING...

comment_text: I like the build quality and amazing attention to detail on the whole LP product range, except the L2 rollers, because gnarling is traditionally used to improving finger grip on rotary knobs, it doesn't really grip things only resting on it. It also tends to lose grip easily unlike rubberised or silicon rollers. They may look aesthetically pleasing, but in my book functionality and practicality ranks much higher.

video_title: Is it worth it?  xTool 40W Diode Laser Review
comment_text: Have some experience with 100w CO2 laser, and I was usually running engraving with 300mm/s speed. Some diode lasers are advertised to be able to run up to 24000mm/min, which is equal to 400mm/s, so theoretically they could do the same as CO2 laser. Perhaps in case of 300mm/s even 40w optical power would not be enough fo good result, but I am confused why people are not running such tests on yt - usually they go up to 10000mm/min.

video_title: $4000 cheaper than Glowforge AND better?  OMTech Polar Review
comment_text: I think there is a lot of nuance in getting the right laser cutter. The Polar looks like an interesting machine and I might be interested if I was getting something for my house. I'm a teacher and the Glowforge works best for my classroom. The footprint is just right for the classroom (looks similar to the Polar). The web interface is a selling point, allowing us to manage multiple users easily and not worry about software. I only use the interface to set up my cuts, where the camera is very useful. Everything else is done in Illustrator, Inkscape, or Vectornator. The subscription is completely optional and unnecessary. Respectfully, the review makes it sound almost required - that is simply incorrect. I have 5 Glowforges (the plus model). They are used constantly, the oldest being 3 years old, and I have never had a serious problem with any of them. Support was quick and helpful when an issue did present itself, the GF was cutting again by the end of the day. It is a no fuss machine - and that is what I need when working with 100 students each quarter. If I were buying a hobby machine I would have different requirements, but the Glowforge is pretty awesome for us. Just wanted to provide a different perspective/experience.

comment_text: The limit function on this kind of driver works by monitoring the amount of current the stepper draws under normal operation vs what it would draw once the motor has stalled. It is closed looped insofar as a circuit reacts to the rapid jump in current (at the speed of light) and cuts the current (steps) to the motor. This is the way it should be done, as limit switches are prone to failure at some point.

comment_text:
I‚Äôve had my eye on the Aeon Mira 5S Redline, and I have a few questions regarding my product line that I plan to work with. I want to make sure the machine fits my specific needs, so I‚Äôm hoping you can provide some insights.

1. Can the engraving and cutting height be automatically adjusted to uneven surfaces (e.g., wavy materials)? Ideally, I‚Äôd like a 3D mapping system where I can freely define the measurement points based on the material. I‚Äôd like to set the number of measurement points per square cm or at least define a measurement area to ensure the engraving or 3D map is as accurate as possible.

2. Is there an automated height detection system or any add-ons for soft materials like leaves or flowers, which are difficult to measure with mechanical height detection?

3. What is the noise level of the machine and the exhaust system? I plan to use it in my home, so that‚Äôs important for me.

4. When working with larger materials that are fed through the machine, is it possible for the engraving or cutting to be automatically detected and seamlessly extended? I‚Äôm looking for intelligent software that can adjust the engraving path automatically without needing to manually realign the material.

5. Do you use or recommend any infeed track with a stopper and optional conveyor belt for precise material alignment and consistent movement at the right angle during the process?

6. Is there an intelligent function for engraving multiple identical materials? I would like the machine to detect and optimize the engraving process across multiple pieces with identical designs, to save time and ensure consistent results.

I know that the xTool P2S has most of the features I need, and their software is actually quite good. However, it seems that they may have purchased reviews on Trustpilot, and their customer support has been quite disappointing, so I don‚Äôt fully trust this company.

I‚Äôm also interested in experimenting with inlays in small QR codes, around 30x30mm, where the glass tube CO2 laser might reach its limits. It could be better to go for an RF option, but I‚Äôm not sure if Aeon is the right choice for this. You may have a better idea of what would suit my needs best, considering you‚Äôve tested a larger product range and are up to date with the latest technologies.

I‚Äôm based in Germany, so it would be good if there aren‚Äôt any issues with shipping or customer support, but that‚Äôs mostly optional.

Best regards

comment_text:
I can think of a theoretical hack to improve the print quality and lower the price of ink:
The cartridge used is the same as the HP 62, and there are two of these, the CMY and the black. If you open the image to be printed in Photoshop and convert it to CMYK and save one copy with only the K channel as grayscale and the other as CMYK but leaving the black channel empty, then you print the color first and then the black one, you will have a real CMYK print. And on the other hand, there are cheaper compatible cartridges for the HP 62 cartridges.
It would be a good video to make.

video_title: I Tested Every Desktop Laser - This is the Best
comment_text: First of all, great review and categorization of thoose lasers! However, as a beginner, I feel like some essential information is missing, especially for desktop models. Next year, I plan to start working with small parts, around 1-4 cm thick. I mostly need engraving, and I‚Äôd like to work on multiple pieces at once (potentially different sizes but the same height), letting the laser run while I do other tasks. For this, the laser should have the capability to automatically detect the position of the workpieces and center engravings, like texts or QR codes. Otherwise, I would have to manually measure and align each piece to the 0,0 point. For example, if one piece is 50mm wide and another is 52mm wide, and I want a QR code centered, the laser should be able to automatically center it if needed. This is especially important when dealing with multiple pieces lying next to each other. I can't rely on precise X, Y coordinates because the pieces might not always be perfectly aligned, or there could be a 1-2 mm gap between them, which could throw off the centering of the engravings.

video_title: The Best Laser Engraver & Cutter to Get at ANY Budget
comment_text:
The only thing better than having your own laser cutter is having a friend who has a laser cutter.......find a friend who has an Xtool P2 or similar.

For safety reasons, I will never be anywhere near an open-frame device even if I'm wearing OD6 (or higher) laser goggles. If you have one of these, at least put an enclosure around it. BTW, a pair of laser safety goggles is a lot cheaper than eye surgery, or living the rest of your life with impaired or no vision.

Air-assist. You really need it to reduce the fire hazard, as it squelches flames that try to form while cutting. Remember, a laser cutter works by burning-away material.

Smoke. You dont realize how MUCH smoke gets produced till you do your first cut. Even a few small cuts on thin MDF or plywood will stink-up your entire garage. Which goes back to the first point: You need an enclosure for safety reasons as well as to gather the smoke for your exhaust fan (or air purifier).

Cooling. We havn't done any lengthy processing on the P2 yet. It's water-cooled and I've only seen the temp go up 1-2 degrees during usage, even when the laser is running at 100% power. A 55W CO2 laser is around 20% efficient, so you probably have 300 watts coming thru the laser tube. It's going to take awhile for that to heat-up a water tank. But if you're using an air-cooled fiber laser, it's going to heat-up faster even though it's a lot more efficient than CO2. Probably a non-issue for hobby work, because your cutter will pause a few times if it needs to cools-down.

video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text:
Great and informative video...  One option you didn't cover with regard to desktop machines is the CO2 machines sourced from China, typically available on eBay.  I went this route about 4yrs ago.  Purchased a 12" x 20", 50W sealed tube CO2 machine for about $1200.  It has many of the features of the more expensive domestically sourced (US made) machines.  It's not quite as refined, but it does the job just fine.   Worked for 30yrs in the industrial laser field and this machine, even though it's a lot cheaper, is every bit a "real" machine as the more expensive ones.  Though I don't use it for "production work", it could...  That said, not sure how long it'll last for with that kind of use, but for hobby users like me, it's the perfect low cost, nearly full featured machine.   The only thing mine doesn't have is a chiller and auto focus.  I use a large bin full of DI water that can be cooled by tossing in a few frozen bottles of bottled water.  Though it doesn't have auto focus, it does have a manual Z-axis table feature and I use a dial indicator to set the height based off the material thickness used.

Again...  Great and very informative video.  Continue to be amazed at the scope and quantity of equipment available to hobbyists these days!

video_title: I Tested Every Desktop Laser - This is the Best
comment_text:
As a Glowforge Pro owner, there are a couple things that you did omit. I have looked at light burn and believe that I could certainly use it. But, for hobbyists and those who are not using their laser printer day in and day out, Glowforge has a remarkably easy to use interface, one that my mother could figure out.

And let's not forget, Apple made there reputation based on software interface and ease of use .

But that said, the detractors are significant and includes several you missed. Important among them is the fact that you have to pay $240 per year just to be able to save your files to the cloud. Because they have you locked in, any file or project you create will disappear within 30 days unless you pay them their ransom. 

Furthermore, and this is a very little known issue, there is absolutely no way to save a project from glowforge's cloud to your desktop or any local storage device. This means that if you spend your time setting up the perfect print and go forage, you can forget about saving it unless you are paying their yearly subscription fee. I am so surprised that nobody has mentioned this as I quit paying my yearly subscription fee and lost hundreds of project files. 

Similar to this videos conclusion, I would not recommend this product to anyone at any price.

video_title: Why is xTool so Popular - The P2S Desktop Laser Review
comment_text:
Does this "smart align - take an image and get a proper placement on the material" really work?
I have tried so many times to use various cameras with Lightburn (Atomstack x20 pro, including the original Atomstack camera kit) to place content precisely - it's ALWAYS disappointing. 

Not only for the obvious reasons: 
If you use material with different thickness, you need to re-calibrate. 
And it's really hard to mount a camera over a laser in a consistent spot: all constructins I have seen with beams and tripods and "mount to a lid" just didn't have the accuracy required for it to be useful. The camera will always move a tiny bit out of calibration.
Not only that, but even if you really mount it as sturdy as possible and have the same thickness of material all the time, it will just by itself loose calibration within 2-3 runs.
Not only that, even if you use fixed jigs (no camera), the laser itself isn't consistent in positioning, you may get 2-5mm shifts randomly.

So all in all the Lightburn camera alignment feature is just a collosal disappointment.

Is that what you show in the video - randomly positioned material with accurate detection and accurate positioning - REALLY REALLY reality or is that staged B.S.? Does it REALLY get the content onto the material in the right angle, in the right place?
Can there be a proper review of this feature, please?

Thanks!

video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text:
Snapmaker 2.0 falls into the "tricked out 3D printer" category, along with the diode modules you install in your 3D printer.
Again no M1 on the list, which is still a viable choice for crafters
Snapmaker Ray 40 is in the wrong category, it's an open frame with optional enclosure.

The open frame category is designed for a low upfront cost and not meant to be used as they are but be equipped with accessories later.

The "desktop diode" category has branched in two directions: one is the crafter category (M1, M1 Ultra, WeCreat, Flux Ador, Aura, Spark) and one is hobby/workshop (S1, Falcon2 Pro, Roly, Genmitsu S8). The crafter machines are getting multifunctional with printing/blade cutting modules, while the hobby ones focus on lasers.

Instead of having an always ticked "enclosure" column, you should add important parameters missing from your sheet:
* how the focus works: by moving the module or bed - as this limits functionality, you can't easily do curved surface processing when the whole bed has to move up and down
* rotary attachment support - out of the box, with optional riser base, etc.
* pass through / removable bottom plate

BTW as far as I know WeCreat somehow shot off xTool (ex employees?) - their software is basically a clone of xCS 1.x.
BTW2 you could have waited with this until the P2S review.

video_title: I was wrong about the xTool D1...
comment_text:
PLEASE! PLEASE! DO NOT BUY - I have spent about $3000 with Xtool - I purchased the D1Pro and some other stuff almost a year ago and I have had nothing but issues. Trying to work with Customer Service is INSANITY! I also purchased the Infrared, and it has never worked. I was told by Xtool "Regarding the problem of the infrared laser head, many customers will not be able to use it successfully due to improper operation." So even if you follow their instructions and use the samples they sent, you still maybe doing something wrong. What are you doing wrong?--- you don't know, and they don't either, so you end up with a $500 paper weight. I watched tons of Youtube reviews on the D1Pro and they all gave glowing reviews; so, I went with it. Unfortunately, I and many others have not had the same success with Xtool as indicated in the Youtube reviews. After so many issues I decided to invest in another laser and speaking to some of Xtool competitors I asked question in hope that I don't end up with $3000 paper weights. The most chilling thing discovered was they are aware of Xtool and the issues the customers face. I noticed that a lot of the issues I've had with Xtool out the gate without me asking any questions they spell out what the machine can and can't do, their customer service and support. One guy said their Support Agents respond with 4 to 9 minutes and they quickly resolve your issue because they understand many of their customer use it for business purposes. Better than the 24 to 72 hours waiting for Xtool to respond and two weeks later you are still no where close to a resolution. OH, and those that have State side support definitely let you know that.

 I really don't want anyone to encounter this; because when you are not a wealthy person $3000 is a huge investment for you. PLEASE when researching for purchase do more than watch YouTube videos; it could save you time, money and peace of mind. PLEASE be sure to ask about customer service\support, warranty, replacement parts. A big one would be "What issues are commonly encountered by customers and how do you work to resolve those issues? 

I saw a post on Facebook asking, "Why are so many people selling their Xtool?" I laughed because I was looking to see how easy it would be to sell it. RFLOL 

When you have a quality product it is GREAT! I really enjoy engraving, cutting and making things it is so therapeutic. DON"T FORGET to be diligent in your research.

video_title: Make This With Your Laser To Leave Your Day Job
comment_text:
Great video. Personally I would leave out packaging cost because that can be put into your shipping price, that the customer pays. 

I would add in misc business costs as a % on top - rent, supplies, kitchen, cleaning, insurance, registrations, safety equipment etc.

As for laser time, i've found that it is unrealistic unless it is the ONLY factor in pricing a custom one off job. A lot of people online use laser time but if you're also factoring machine cost, maintenance and labour, then counting laser time is basically double charging (in terms of working out your costs). 

However it does work in figuring out how to price a custom jobs on the fly, where you aren't making the same kind of item hundreds of times.

Ultimately if you are making at least 3-4x the cost of materials then you're doing alright.

comment_text:
I see 2-3 slight ‚Äúproblems‚Äù:

1.) It is slightly more difficult to figure out/see exactly where it will engrave, especially when not using the matt.

2.) The hight of materials, as well as potential waviness, seem very restricted! Many other cheaper diode lasers have auto leveling via stepper motor and height detection DURING engraving, and don‚Äôt rely on a roller in a specific location.

3.) The overall concept saves storage and transportation space, but is very limiting otherwise. Including (inexpensive) expansion kits, higher power laser modules etc.

Interesting product (for specific applications)!

Best wishes

comment_text:
There is no free lunch with lasers.  If it is underpowered it will cut in a more shallow way and it will require lower speeds for engraving deeper.   

For laser work, remember the price, quality, and speed triangle:

Fast!
Cheap!
Good!

Now pick two options but only two options. 
Remember this triangle because it rules your world.  You might want to reach an economy of scale, but for that you need a lot of capital.

video_title: This is The Best Laser Cutter and Engraver
comment_text: I have owned several lasers over time. From my first Laser Master 2, to the Xtool S1 and P2. I wish I had known about the survey, I would have contributed. I actually sold my P2 because it was just way too cumbersome. The Xtool machines are a good bang for your buck, but there are two things I absolutely HATE about them. 1st, the hose size for the exhaust tubing is 3 inch. This means it won't fit most standard duct tubing which is 4 inches or more. I had to print adapters for the S1 and P2. There is no good reason for them not to use the most common size. Though I guess this could be some attempt at proprietary BS so that you have to buy tubing and exhaust accessories from them. 2nd, the implementation of lightburn compatibility is terrible. It's janky as all hell and badly thought out. Plus the camera functions of the P2 never worked in lightburn for me. If I could do it again, I would go with a company like Thunder Laser. They are also Chinese, but they have USA based support and sales people. So my issues are never brushed aside and the BS claims are less.

video_title: Finally an Easy Way to Make Laser Cut Maps!
comment_text: I make and sell laser engraved wooden and color printed maps, major cities, towns even area and streets, so they sell well. I have used quite a few different software programs to accomplish my goals. I used QGIS for when I needed buildings, Snazzy Maps for streets, roads and highways, finally Open Street Map for a little bit of both. Snazzy is the easiest but you can‚Äôt export SVG files for editing, nor does it do buildings at the resolution I need. QGIS and Open Street Map both do buildings but have Steeper leaning curves with multiple steps and that slows down my workflow. I would love to offer custom maps, but the time it takes me to design one map, to sell that one map, makes it a poor financial decision (time is money). I have other products that are far easier to make, and therefore more profitable. If Laser Map Maker is easier to use and can draw up buildings and exports SVG files, then I can make custom maps faster and make more money, then it is a good deal to me.

I clicked on the link to see how much these are going to cost, since as of right now it is only a pre-order. There were a lot of ways to contact them to have them get back to you, but no way to actually find out the price without them having your contact info and being able to possibly spam you with sales calls. Maybe I'm the only one, but that makes this a non-starter for me. I used to teach laser cutting at a maker space on a $75,000 laser cutter (I did not own it), so I know they can get up there, and I'm sure this one is no where near that. But, I'm not going to jump through hoops to find out.

Some people will say, "Well, if you have to ask, you can't afford it." Except that if you are a small shop, and have a budget, it is actually possible that you could afford it, and you would like to know so you can set aside the money,.......   

It's more like, "If your potential customer has to ask, then you probably shouldn't be hiding it."

video_title: Can You Trust Product Reviews?
comment_text:
Thank you for tackling what could be a thorny subject. Personally I always love to listen to reviewers' takes on the machines and I usually form some opinion using an aggregate of reviews. And even this only forms part of my overall opinion. Reviews are great but they never take the place of doing your own hard research. And you have to accept that MOST of these lasers are built in part or in whole in China where the quality is not always consistent. So no matter what you do you may end up with a bad sample of an otherwise good laser. I am much more concerned about the company I am buying from and their customer service than the actual laser itself 99% of the time.

But that being said I do thing the reviews have value as long as nobody doing them tries to hide the fact that they received the laser for free for review. Honesty and openness are the requirement for these reviews to have any merit. You have never given me any reason to think you are otherwise so I love following your channel.

video_title: This is the World's Fastest Laser
comment_text: I watch you regularly, and expected that your knowledge level would be a bit higher. First, she talks about the speed. Owning an Epilog Fusion Pro, I know something about speed. At top speed and max output power, you are hardly leaving a mark on wood. So, the speed argument is a little dumb. The accordions on the side of the gantry to protect the internals of the machine is something Epilog has had for years. The idea that somehow, the autofocus built-in to the lens carriage is something new is also wrong. Epilog, Trotec, and honestly several others I can think of have been doing that for years. Servo motors? Welcome to 2020. Let's talk resolution. 1000 DPI, is nowhere near class-leading. She talks about how happy she is about how rigid they are, being built of steel. Why did they add several hundred pounds to the machine by cheapening out with steel when they should have gone with military grade aluminum. I notice that my Epilog is under 300 pounds while the Aeon with the same bed size is 550 pounds. Some of them go up to 1,500 pounds. She talks about being able to change frequency, well I am not certain, but I think several companies have had that for years. I know I can change that on mine. The drop-in water cooled tube that doesn't change alignment is cool, bravo on that point! Even if you could buy one, (many people can not get a regular Mira for months) some interviews have said their Signature series (the only one that can boast all of this speed and ceramic RF core) is not even on the horizon for 4 to 6 months. Last thing is price. Who in the name of all that is holy is going to pay Epilog prices for a Chinese machine? I think it is just a reverse engineered Epilog or Trotec. There was a time when I would have looked at an Aeon or Thunder, but they were just too slow for my production needs. And please, add an LCD screen! What a strange place to try to save a buck, the one thing you will touch EVERY SINGLE TIME YOU USE THE LASER!

comment_text: I own the F2P as well and I'm a bit saddened by the inability to raise the z-height on this unit, despite being promoted on Creality's own listing page. I suggest anyone looking into this printer be VERY cautious. You're paying a lot of money for a supposedly versatile tool. If you think someday you might use a rotary tool on this thing -- you probably won't. The tray CANNOT be removed to extend the legs so you can fit a rotary. The device uses a magnetic switch to detect when it's removed, and shuts off the laser. So just be aware that you are basically buying a $300 CNC laser with a $20 lid on it and a PC case fan to vent it.

video_title: $2K Cheaper, 2X Better? - The Thunder Bolt Desktop Laser
comment_text:
I've watched other comparisons where actual cutting time was measured. Before fully understanding the logic used to control the laser, I was surprised to see that machines with 600 to 1,000 mm speeds could only produce parts at roughly the same run time as machines with a maximum speed of 300 to 400 mm. The reason is that the faster machines have to overshoot the work area when ramping up and slowing down.

Ultimately, the best choice of laser comes down to (1) the purpose you intend to use it for (cutting or fine engraving) and (2) how fast it can perform the required task.

I would buy a 600mm square 40W laser over a 300mm square 70w laser for a similar price and it wouldn't even be a difficult choice.....

video_title: Worth it? How the xTool P2 CO2 Laser Stacks Up Against the Competition
comment_text: Xtool advertising is misleading. They say the P2 works with Lightburn (with exception of auto focus, cameras and curve feature). Given i already have a D1 and Lightburn works perfectly with it, I had no reason to assume Lightburn wouldn't work with the P2 with the exception of the explicitly stated limitations above.  I can understand not having the curve support, but all other functions should be available. Also, the XCS software is horrible. I would not expect it to be on par with LIghtburn, but there are a multitude of little things like being able to easily define layers or remove the close up view when not needed. All in all, unless you are happy to only work in XCS (assuming full support for Lightburn never comes), save your money and buy another brand CO2 (Monoport, Omtech) and get a fiber laser to go with it for what you pay for the P2. I am posting this comment not as a criticism of the this video, but in the hopes that someone watching this video in trying to decide whether to buy the P2 or not, are more fully informed. I did a fair amount of research before buying the P2 and everyone either intentionally or unknowingly failed to mention just how limited LIghtburn for P2 is nor just how bad the XCS software is.
