video_title: You Could Lose Your Job To This.
comment_text:
I think you are spot on in your analysis. You went back to 1928, but let‚Äôs go further back: We saw the same trends with new technologies like electricity, the steam engine (revolutionised the weaving industry), the wheel‚Ä¶. Each time, we have seen new jobs emerge as a result.

For woodworkers, we can be divided into two categories: Some are production focussed, churning out the same chairs, tables, coasters every day in as high a volume as possible. For them, automation will be a God-send as they will be able to produce more a day. The other category are the more ‚Äúcreative‚Äù (no offence, producers) that hardly ever make two identical products. Here, machines may replace certain steps, but not the entire creative and assembly process. It‚Äôs especially the creative work that AI cannot replace - at least for many years to come.

video_title: You Could Lose Your Job To This.
comment_text:
You asked for feedback, so here goes with the caveat that not every channel should be for everyone and every creator should have the space to evolve.
I'm just here for information about tools and process, not the larger context. For the current machine learning wave as a topic, I'd be interested in seeing what you can *do* with it but if I want a historical or economic perspective (both topics notoriously filled with misinformation) then  I'll go read or watch a historian or an economist.
But, like I said, just because it's not for me doesn't mean it's not for others and it definitely doesn't mean that you shouldn't head in new directions with the channel.

comment_text:
I believe that opening the vent enables air INTO the machine which can then go to the exhaust. Without the vent opening, this sealed machine will have no way for fresh air to get into the machine at a high enough volume to not starve the filter. It‚Äôs clever, as the vent is in the front top, while the exhaust is in the middle height at the rear. So this gives you an air flow that goes right through the shortest distance, which happens to be the area where the laser is working.

If the size of the bed is ok for people and you just don‚Äôt have the room, then this is fine. The quality seems to be pretty good. As far as the different time scales for the laser or the printer, well, you just have to manage your time. If you know what you‚Äôre going to be doing, then do the short job first. These things are a compromise. If you‚Äôre willing to accept that, then it‚Äôs great. If you can‚Äôt, then this isn‚Äôt the machine for you. But don‚Äôt forget this also cuts and draws. This might be useful and it may not.

video_title: Do Lasers Ruin 3D Printer‚Äôs? Bambu Lab H2D Laser Review
comment_text:
Absolutely save the money and buy a dedicated laser printer.  The difference that you didn't mention when you compared the additional cost  of the 40W Bambu when compared to just buying the S1 is the cut size.  The camera is a nice feature, but with the alignment functions of the S1 it is minimal.  Having roughly twice the cut capacity, plus having a dedicated machine is going to completely offset the few hundred dollar difference.  Plus, XCS is a great software solution on it's own for beginners, but you can use LightBurn on the S1 when you grow beyond the limited feature set you get with Bambu Studio.

Additionally, I guarantee that the more you use the laser, the more dirty the inside of the 3D printer is going to get.  Take a picture of the inside of a P2 or P2S that gets daily use and you'll see what I mean.

Finally, the problem with having a shared machine is that when the H2D eventually has a failure, you lose all of your ability to work whereas if you have different machines, you can at least still do something.

video_title: Do Lasers Ruin 3D Printer‚Äôs? Bambu Lab H2D Laser Review
comment_text: Awkwardly, I wish they'd release the Laser edition without the laser module.  That may sound a bit odd, but the laser module is already shipped separately from the printer itself, and the Laser edition actually has other features that the non-Laser variants do not such as cutting and drawing.  Once the laser module is sold separately (I didn't find it on their store at the time of writing), then you could buy one when/if you wanted one.  They have talked about releasing an upgrade kit for the basic H2D, but given that the upgrade kit just puts you at the same level as a H2D Laser without the laser, I'd rather just buy that from the start.

video_title: How Good is the Atomstack Hurricane Desktop Laser?
comment_text: Update to delivery issues on this machine.  After contesting the charge on my credit card, whether that had anything to do with it or not (?), I did finally receive all ordered items.  The rotary was broken and AtomStack replaced that within a week.  With the exception of the 3rd mirror adjustment at the laser head - difficult to adjust due to the air assist tubing and the auto focusing wires disconnecting regularly (faulty connecter), oh and the decision not to provide free shipping so I'm still out $400, the machine is actually pretty good so far.  Pro: very robust metal build, this thing is solid! Proprietary software is good, I use both that and Lightburn, depending on what I am doing, and it is pretty precise.  Cons: difficult lens adjustment (laser head design could have been a bit better at little extra effort), rotary accessories are workable but made of plastic and don't have the same sturdiness of the laser (honestly, it's a beast!), but they work, just be gentle with them.  Support is decent.  I ordered during the Dragon Festival so that holiday gummed up the customer service a bit.  Expect delays in response due to  being on the other side of the world and the language barrier... some of the replies were difficult to decipher due to the language barrier.  Overall - I'm growing to really like this machine.

video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text:
Warning!

Cheapest "open laser" is not a professional equipment. The smoke, exhaust fumes can kill you - cancer is a likely possibility. The smell of exhaust fumes is unbearable. The burnt dust that is created during cutting or engraving is sticky and smelly. If you do not have a closed box laser with an activated carbon filter or at least an exhaust system outside the workshop, do not think about the laser business. These toys for a few hundred dollars are only suitable for amateur fun - no protection against the laser beam (risk of eye damage), toxic fumes, low power, low speed. comment_text:
Working with cutting lasers about 10 years ago for glass. We used mirrors to transmit the beam, with a focus setup on the head to adjust the final focus point and to compensate for the fluctuating movement.

Other setups used a scan head, 2 mirrors that would adjust x,y, with another focal lens to adjust for z as x,y changed the z distance changed from the point of emittance.

The distance was a few feet from the working surface.

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text:
Being in school photography since 2016, I have lots of experience with printers. And the of the biggest issues are with the print head and ink.

- Ink tends to dry out and clog. Any news on how thos is handled with the resin? I known it's UV resin and doesn't exactly dry out. But over time, it can still happen. Colored resin isn't just resin. There's still ink particles that can clump up when sitting idle.

- The print head is easily the most annoying component. They shift and rare out over time. They're not easy nor cheap to replace. And it's not like we can just call a repair shop to come over and fix this one.

- I've ran into far too many issues with the ink spilling all over the printhead and down onto the paper and internal components. How would that be addressed with this printer? Resin would be a lot more difficult to remove than traditional liquid or powder ink.

- To add to that, how easy is it to repair/place the print bed components? The belt, the gears, etc?

video_title: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printer
comment_text:
Nah... most of us that are deep into printing, know that there's only a handful of chemical ink producers, and it's no longer the 90s, and basically everyone follows very similar formulas and pigment densities. UV ink is only special in it's resin binder that's activated by very specific wavelength of UV light. The most common is 395um. But even still many commercial UV inks will cure within a range of 385um to 405um.

That being said... if I bought this printer, the first thing I would do is learn the cartridge system, and see if they are chip coding them or not. And secondly, if there was a way to non-destructively refill them. BECAUSE, even really good 3rd party UV ink should only cost you between $15-20 per liter. There might be some variance on the white, it's particle size and what specific inkjet heads they are using. Again, this is a start-up, so I promise you they aren't designing their own piezo electric print heads from scratch. They are sourcing them from Ricoh or Epson. If you know which one, you can buy inks specifically tailored to that particular print head. It's not that complicated.

Remember, ALL printer companies make their business model around you, the customer always buying ink from them, keeping them in business.

I'd hoped companies would take note after the BambuLab "this is how we will operate going forward" backlash but looks like more *asterisk* stuff could be on the radar. 

Thanks for the updates again. See if you can get more information on the subscription tiers/specifics. If it's anything like Adobe (which I love, but costs a bit) then this is something to definitely factor into the cost of printing products as well as the ink.

Imagine a tradeshow/event with a line of 20+ clients and you run out of "credits" for generation...ChatGPT like tiers? Free - $20 - $200?....scary...

video_title: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV Printer
comment_text:
Established companies like Anker, the owner of Eufy, should not be using Kickstarter as a funding platform. These corporations have ample financial resources to support their own projects, yet they turn to crowdfunding as a way to shift all risk onto consumers and backers. If their product fails‚Äîlike their previous 3D printers‚Äîthese companies remain unaffected, profiting from sold units while losing nothing on research and development.
What makes this situation particularly concerning is that working units of the product already exist, as multiple YouTubers have demonstrated in their reviews. So what, exactly, is being ‚ÄúKickstarted‚Äù? The manufacturing process? This is not what Kickstarter was originally intended for. Unfortunately, more and more established and profitable companies continue to exploit the platform, using it as a shield to protect their investments rather than a genuine tool for innovation.
This unethical practice places all financial risk on backers, who are left vulnerable if the product fails. Meanwhile, content creators often enable this cycle by eagerly accepting free units and promoting them without scrutiny. If influencers refused to provide exposure to these companies without genuine accountability, failed launches could force corporations to rethink their approach and adhere to proper business practices.

comment_text: I put down my deposit so now I'm just waiting for the Kick to start.  I have a few questions, I'm hoping you can answer.  1) How long do the resin cartridges last, ie: how much can you print?  I know that is somewhat subjective, based on what you print, and how much of each color you use, but take your Mando print on wood.  How much resin did that take?  How many of those could you print with a single kit?  2) Since the printer has to lay down a white layer under anything that isn't being printed on a white surface, is the white tank bigger than the colors?  I think I saw somewhere that the ink kit would be around $300 to replace, and if you're going through that (and/or a cleaning kit) every few months, that has a pretty high cost of usage.  3) I saw another video about printing on tumblers and cups and it seemed to suggest that the machine was pretty picky about the sizes and shapes of tumblers it works with.  The ones you demo'd appear to be Eufy branded, so not just any old tumbler.  It loses a lot of flexibility if you can only print on their materials.  4) The sticker lamination set up looks like it might require some kind of transfer material, and I'm wondering if that is also proprietary.  I live in Alaska, so I'm really cautious about new tech with proprietary media / materials, because all too often companies don't ship to Alaska or treat it like a completely foreign country.  ($200 to ship a $99 thing - Xtool won't even ship replacement lenses or mirrors to Alaska).  Thanks in advance.

I have 2 concerns. A craftsman should own his tools or he will never get anywhere in life. $20 bucks a month to rent software is crazy!

My 2nd concern is the whole idea of vaporizing metal as opposed to machining away metal.

A small home cnc mill could use the same image to cut the metal away. The metal shavings could be melted down or sold as scrap.

Venting the vaporized metal fumes in or even outside the home still sounds like a bad idea in the long run.

video_title: Create Pro Product Photos Instantly (No Fancy Setup Needed!)
comment_text:
Wait, if it's taking an existing image and then just putting your product in it, as you showed in the example with the Emma tag on the folded napkin, how is that not plagiarism? It's not like it's even really making a new image, you're literally feeding it the image you're copying, call it inspiration all you like, but it's just plagiarism with the extra step of telling the computer to do it for you. And frankly, why bother with chatGPT if you're just gonna plagiarize things, you can already do that for free.

As for selling your photos with generated images of your product, I would say that's just false advertising. If you're portraying something as a photo of the product, and it's not a photo of the product, you're just lying, again, with extra steps. And sure, if you want to sell your product by lying, that's hardly a new idea - just ask El Nasir - but let's at least be honest with ourselves about what we're doing here.

Look, man, I'm not entirely against AI being used as a tool. There are even ethically trained AI models out there(even if ChatGPT isn't one of them). But this this isn't helping folks, it's the opposite. It's just a way to have people offload essential - and fairly easy to learn, in my experience - skills for a creative business to a tool they don't control, and ensuring they are turbo-screwed when those tools change or go away, as well as essentially telling people to do sketchy and in some given examples downright unethical things like it's normal and fine.

If you want an example, let's say, hey, someone spun up a business doing portraits of people in Ghibli style using chatGPT...they'd have some angry customers right about now, because in the time between filming and this video being made, ChatGPT has taken that feature offline, with no indication of when it will return. Which is especially ironic, considering Brandon's quite reasonable complaints with hardware about not having it in your control, and a third party being able to shut you down arbitrarily, at any time, with no recourse.

And no, I don't expect this comment to last too long, a few hours at most, whenever Brandon's part of the US wakes up. But that's fair enough, I've said my piece, so no skin off my nose.

video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text:
Laser diodes are currently limited to about 5W of output power under ideal conditions, which means that any diode laser with a higher power will have multiple diodes. This introduces a problem in that it is very difficult to get all the beams lined up, so the beam is often not very well focused. You will note that I said OUTPUT power. The problem with a lot of diode lasers you might find on Aliexpress or Ebay is that the seller is listing the INPUT electrical power, which is usually about 4 to 5 times the output power. Yep, most of the input power gets turned into heat. 

A diode laser with a genuine 40W output will consume a least 160W, and will be turning about 120W of the input power into heat. That's if you actually have a 160W power supply for it. If it doesn't have a massive heatsink, it probably isn't a 40W laser.

So you need to be careful when buying a diode laser, particularly a cheap one from China. Your 40W diode laser is probably only giving you 5W or 10W of actual output power.

video_title: CNC vs Laser vs 3D Printer - Which is BEST?
comment_text:
Can the same CAD software be used, whether your final material is wood, plastic, or metal?

For example, some CAD software is tied to the shop that will fabricate it..  eMachineShop or Protocase Designer CAD..  but what if you want to do it first in a different material?

What CAD software do you recommend?   From what' I've seen:

Fusion360 is great for design, but the cost/license might be a deal-breaker for many 
Parametric (i.e. ability to undo as many steps as you want) is a must-have feature
FreeCAD might be a bit difficult for the beginner
OnShape supports exporting without having the $2500/year license
Pro/Corporate Users should stick with Siemens Solid Edge , Solidworks, Catia, Pro-Engineer
Then there's other that don't have nearly as much users.. Moi3D, OctoPrint, etc.

but for most beginners, it seems TinkerCad and Plasticity are the solid choices?

BTW, do you recommend any low-cost 3d printer service?  Sculpteo , Shapeways, CraftCloud, xometry, protolabs?  How about for CNC / Laser ?
